1.1: In the beginning, God created the universe.
1.2: When the earth was as yet unformed and desolate, with the surface of the ocean depths shrouded in darkness, and while the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the waters,
1.3: God said, "Let there be light!" So there was light.
1.4: God saw that the light was beautiful. He separated the light from the darkness,
1.5: calling the light "day," and the darkness "night." The twilight and the dawn were day one.
1.6: Then God said, "Let there be a canopy between bodies of water, separating bodies of water from bodies of water!"
1.7: So God made a canopy that separated the water beneath the canopy from the water above it. And that is what happened:
1.8: God called the canopy "sky." The twilight and the dawn were the second day.
1.9: Then God said, "Let the water beneath the sky come together into one area, and let dry ground appear!" And that is what happened:
1.10: God called the dry ground "land," and he called the water that had come together "oceans." And God saw how good it was.
1.11: Then God said, "Let vegetation sprout all over the earth, including seed-bearing plants and fruit trees, each kind containing its own seed!" And that is what happened:
1.12: Vegetation sprouted all over the earth, including seed-bearing plants and fruit trees, each kind containing its own seed. And God saw that it was good.
1.13: The twilight and the dawn were the third day.
1.14: Then God said, "Let there be lights across the sky to distinguish day from night, to act as signs for seasons, days, and years,
1.15: to serve as lights in the sky, and to shine on the earth!" And that is what happened:
1.16: God fashioned two great lights—the larger light to shine during the day and the smaller light to shine during the night—as well as stars.
1.17: God placed them in space to shine on the earth,
1.18: to differentiate between day and night, and to distinguish light from darkness. And God saw how good it was.
1.19: The twilight and the dawn were the fourth day.
1.20: Then God said, "Let the oceans swarm with living creatures, and let flying creatures soar above the earth throughout the sky!"
1.21: So God created every kind of magnificent marine creature, every kind of living marine crawler with which the waters swarmed, and every kind of flying creature. And God saw how good it was.
1.22: God blessed them by saying, "Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the oceans. Let the birds multiply throughout the earth!"
1.23: The twilight and the dawn were the fifth day.
1.24: Then God said, "Let the earth bring forth each kind of living creature, each kind of livestock and crawling thing, and each kind of earth's animals!" And that is what happened:
1.25: God made each kind of the earth's animals, along with every kind of livestock and crawling thing. And God saw how good it was.
1.26: Then God said, "Let us make mankind in our image, to be like us. Let them be masters over the fish in the ocean, the birds that fly, the livestock, everything that crawls on the earth, and over the earth itself!"
1.27: So God created mankind in his own image; in his own image God created them; he created them male and female.
1.28: God blessed the humans by saying to them, "Be fruitful, multiply, fill the earth, and subdue it! Be masters over the fish in the ocean, the birds that fly, and every living thing that crawls on the earth!"
1.29: God also told them, "Look! I have given you every seed-bearing plant that grows throughout the earth, along with every tree that grows seed-bearing fruit. They will produce your food.
1.30: I have given all green plants as food for every wild animal of the earth, every bird that flies, and to every living thing that crawls on the earth." And that is what happened.
1.31: Now God saw all that he had made, and indeed, it was very good! The twilight and the dawn were the sixth day.

2.1: With this the heavens and the earth were completed, including all of their vast array.
2.2: By the seventh day God had completed the work he had been doing, so on the seventh day he stopped working on everything that he had done.
2.3: Then God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it God stopped working on everything that he had been creating.
2.4: These are the records of the universe at its creation. On the day that the LORD God made the earth and skies,
2.5: no shrubs had yet grown in the meadows of the earth and no vegetation had sprouted, because the LORD God had not sent rain on the earth and there were no human beings to work the ground.
2.6: Instead, an underground stream would arise out of the earth and water the surface of the ground.
2.7: So the LORD God formed the man from the dust of the ground, breathed life into his lungs, and the man became a living being.
2.8: The LORD God planted a garden in Eden, toward the east, where he placed the man whom he had formed.
2.9: The LORD God caused every tree that is both beautiful and suitable for food to spring up out of the ground. The tree of life was also in the middle of the garden, along with the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
2.10: A river flows from Eden to water the garden, and from there it divides, becoming four branches.
2.11: The name of the first one is Pishon—it winds through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold.
2.12: The gold of that land is pure; bdellium and onyx are also found there.
2.13: The name of the second river is Gihon— it winds through the entire land of Cush.
2.14: The third river is named the Tigris— it flows to the east of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
2.15: The LORD God took the man and placed him in the Garden of Eden in order to have him work it and guard it.
2.16: The LORD God commanded the man: "You may freely eat from every tree of the garden,
2.17: but you are not to eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, because you will certainly die during the day that you eat from it."
2.18: Later, the LORD God said, "It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make the woman to be an authority corresponding to him."
2.19: After the LORD God formed from the ground every wild animal and every bird that flies, he brought each of them to the man to see what he would call it. Whatever the man called each living creature became its name.
2.20: The man gave names to all the livestock, to the birds that fly, and to each of earth's animals, but there was not found a strength corresponding to him,
2.21: so the LORD God caused a deep sleep to overshadow the man. When the man was asleep, he removed one of the man's ribs and closed up the flesh where it had been.
2.22: Then the LORD God formed the rib that he had taken from the man into a woman and brought her to the man.
2.23: So the man exclaimed, "At last! This is bone from my bones and flesh from my flesh. This one will be called 'Woman,' because she was taken from Man."
2.24: (Therefore a man will leave his father and his mother and cling to his wife, and they will become one flesh.)
2.25: Even though both the man and his wife were naked, they were not ashamed about it.

3.1: Now the Shining One was more clever than any animal of the field that the LORD God had made. It asked the woman, "Did God actually say, 'You are not to eat from any tree of the garden'?"
3.2: "We may eat from the trees of the garden," the woman answered the serpent,
3.3: "but as for the fruit of the tree that is in the middle of the garden, God has said, 'You are not to eat from it, nor are you to touch it, or you will die.'"
3.4: "You certainly will not die!" the Shining One told the woman.
3.5: "Even God knows that on the day you eat from it, your eyes will be opened and you'll become like God, knowing good and evil."
3.6: When the woman saw that the tree produced good food, was attractive in appearance, and was desirable for making one wise, she took some of its fruit and ate it. Then she also gave some to her husband who was with her, and he ate some, too.
3.7: As a result, they both understood what they had done, and they became aware that they were naked. So they sewed fig leaves together and made loincloths for themselves.
3.8: When they heard the voice of the LORD God as he was walking in the garden during the breeze of the day, the man and his wife concealed themselves from the presence of the LORD God among the trees of the garden.
3.9: So the LORD God called out to the man, asking him, "Where are you?"
3.10: "I heard your voice in the garden," the man answered, "and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid from you."
3.11: "Who told you that you are naked?" God asked. "Did you eat fruit from the tree that I commanded you not to eat?"
3.12: The man answered, "The woman whom you provided for me gave me fruit from the tree, and I ate some of it."
3.13: Then the LORD God asked the woman, "What did you do?" "The Shining One misled me," the woman answered, "so I ate."
3.14: The LORD God told the Shining One, "Because you have done this, you are more cursed than all the livestock, and more than all the earth's animals, You'll crawl on your belly and eat dust as long as you live.
3.15: "I'll place hostility between you and the woman, between your offspring and her offspring. He'll strike you on the head, and you'll strike him on the heel."
3.16: He told the woman, "I'll greatly increase the pain of your labor during childbirth. It will be painful for you to bear children, "since your trust is turning toward your husband, and he will dominate you."
3.17: He told the man, "Because you have listened to what your wife said, and have eaten from the tree about which I commanded you, 'You must not eat from it,' cursed is the ground because of you. You'll eat from it through pain-filled labor for the rest of your life.
3.18: It will produce thorns and thistles for you, and you'll eat the plants from the meadows.
3.19: You will eat food by the sweat of your brow until you're buried in the ground, because you were taken from it. You're made from dust and you'll return to dust."
3.20: Now Adam had named his wife "Eve," because she was to become the mother of everyone who was living.
3.21: The LORD God fashioned garments from animal skins for Adam and his wife, and clothed them.
3.22: Later, the LORD God said, "Look! The man has become like one of us in knowing good and evil. Now, so he won't reach out, also take from the tree of life, eat, and then live forever—"
3.23: therefore the LORD God expelled the man from the garden of Eden so he would work the ground from which he had been taken.
3.24: After he had expelled the man, the LORD God placed winged angels at the eastern end of the garden of Eden, along with a fiery, turning sword, to prevent access to the tree of life.

4.1: Later, Adam had sexual relations with his wife Eve. She became pregnant and gave birth to Cain. She said, "I have given birth to a male child—the LORD."
4.2: And she did it again, giving birth to his brother Abel. Abel shepherded flocks and Cain became a farmer.
4.3: Later, after a while, Cain brought an offering to the LORD from the fruit that he had harvested,
4.4: while Abel brought the best parts of some of the firstborn from his flock. The LORD looked favorably upon Abel and his offering,
4.5: but he did not look favorably upon Cain and his offering. When Cain became very upset and depressed,
4.6: the LORD asked Cain, "Why are you so upset? Why are you depressed?
4.7: If you do what is appropriate, you'll be accepted, won't you? But if you don't do what is appropriate, sin is crouching near your doorway, turning toward you. Now as for you, will you take dominion over it?"
4.8: Instead, Cain told his brother Abel, "Let's go out to the wilderness." When they were outside in the fields, Cain attacked his brother Abel and killed him.
4.9: Later, the LORD asked Cain, "Where's your brother Abel?" "I don't know," he answered. "Am I my brother's guardian?"
4.10: "What did you do?" God asked. "Your brother's blood cries out to me from the ground.
4.11: Now you're more cursed than the ground, which has opened to receive your brother's blood from your hand.
4.12: Whenever you work the ground, it will no longer yield its produce to you, and you'll wander throughout the earth as a fugitive."
4.13: "My punishment is too great to bear," Cain told the LORD.
4.14: "You're driving me from the soil today. I'll be hidden from you, and I'll wander throughout the earth as a fugitive. In the future, whoever finds me will kill me."
4.15: The LORD told him, "This won't happen, because whoever kills you will suffer seven times the vengeance." Then the LORD placed a sign on Cain so that no one finding him would kill him.
4.16: After this, Cain left the presence of the LORD and settled in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
4.17: Later, Cain had sexual relations with his wife. She became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. Cain founded a city and named it after his son Enoch.
4.18: Irad was born to Enoch. Irad fathered Mehujael, and Mehujael fathered Methushael, and Methushael fathered Lamech.
4.19: Later, Lamech married two wives. One was named Adah and the other was named Zillah.
4.20: Adah gave birth to Jabal, who became the ancestor of those who live in tents and herd livestock.
4.21: His brother was named Jubal; he became the ancestor of all those who play the lyre and the flute.
4.22: Zillah gave birth to Tubal-cain, who became a forger of bronze and iron work. Tubal-cain's sister was Naamah.
4.23: Lamech told his wives, "Adah and Zillah, listen to what I have to say: You wives of Lamech, hear what I'm announcing! I've killed a man for wounding me, a young man for bruising me.
4.24: For if Cain is being avenged seven times, then Lamech will be avenged 77 times."
4.25: Later on, after Adam had sexual relations with his wife, she gave birth to a son and named him Seth, because "God granted me another offspring to replace Abel, since Cain murdered him."
4.26: Seth also fathered a son, whom he named Enosh. At that time, profaning the name of the LORD began.

5.1: This is the historical record of Adam's generations. When God created mankind, he made them in his own likeness.
5.2: Creating them male and female, he blessed them and called them humans when he created them.
5.3: After Adam had lived 130 years, he fathered a son just like him, that is, according to his own likeness, and named him Seth.
5.4: Adam lived another 800 years, fathering other sons and daughters after he had fathered Seth.
5.5: Adam lived a total of 930 years, and then died.
5.6: When Seth had lived 105 years, he fathered Enosh.
5.7: After he fathered Enosh, Seth lived 807 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.8: Seth lived a total of 912 years, and then died.
5.9: When Enosh had lived 90 years, he fathered Kenan.
5.10: After he fathered Kenan, Enosh lived 815 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.11: Enosh lived a total of 905 years, and then died.
5.12: When Kenan had lived 70 years, he fathered Mahalalel.
5.13: After he fathered Mahalalel, Kenan lived 840 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.14: Kenan lived a total of 910 years, and then died.
5.15: When Mahalalel had lived 65 years, he fathered Jared.
5.16: After he fathered Jared, Mahalalel lived 830 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.17: Mahalalel lived a total of 895 years, and then died.
5.18: When Jared had lived 162 years, he fathered Enoch.
5.19: After he fathered Enoch, Jared lived 800 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.20: Jared lived a total of 962 years, and then died.
5.21: When Enoch had lived 65 years, he fathered Methuselah.
5.22: After he fathered Methuselah, Enoch communed with God for 300 years and fathered other sons and daughters.
5.23: Enoch lived a total of 365 years,
5.24: communing with God—and then he was there no longer, because God had taken him.
5.25: When Methuselah had lived 187 years, he fathered Lamech.
5.26: After he fathered Lamech, Methuselah lived 782 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.27: Methuselah lived a total of 969 years, and then died.
5.28: When Lamech had lived 182 years, he fathered a son,
5.29: whom he named Noah, because he said, "May this one comfort us from our work, from pain that is caused by our manual labor, and from the ground that the LORD has cursed."
5.30: After he fathered Noah, Lamech lived 595 years, fathering other sons and daughters.
5.31: Lamech lived a total of 777 years, and then died.
5.32: After Noah had lived 500 years, he fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

6.1: Now after the population of human beings had increased throughout the earth, and daughters had been born to them,
6.2: some divine beings noticed how attractive human women were, so they took wives for themselves from a selection that pleased them.
6.3: So the LORD said, "My Spirit won't remain with human beings forever, because they're truly mortal. Their lifespan will be 120 years."
6.4: The Nephilim were on the earth at that time (and also immediately afterward), when those divine beings were having sexual relations with those human women, who gave birth to children for them. These children became the heroes and legendary figures of ancient times.
6.5: The LORD saw that human evil was growing more and more throughout the earth, with every inclination of people's thoughts becoming only evil on a continuous basis.
6.6: Then the LORD regretted that he had made human beings on the earth, and he was deeply grieved about that.
6.7: So the LORD said, "I will annihilate these human beings whom I've created from the earth, including people, animals, crawling things, and flying creatures, because I'm grieving that I made them."
6.8: The LORD was pleased with Noah, however.
6.9: These are the family records of Noah: Noah was a righteous man. Blameless during his times, Noah communed with God.
6.10: Noah fathered three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
6.11: By this time, the earth had become ruined in God's opinion and filled with violence.
6.12: God looked at the earth, observing how corrupt its population had become, because the entire human race had corrupted itself.
6.13: So God announced to Noah, "I've decided to destroy every living thing on earth, because it has become filled with violence due to them. Look! I'm about to annihilate them, along with the earth.
6.14: So make yourself an ark out of cedar, constructing compartments in it, and cover it inside and out with tar.
6.15: Make the ark like this: 300 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, and 30 cubits high.
6.16: Make a roof for the ark, and finish the walls to within one cubit from the top. Place the entrance in the side of the ark, and build a lower, a middle, and an upper deck.
6.17: "For my part, I'm about to flood the earth with water and destroy every living thing that breathes. Everything on earth will die.
6.18: However, I will establish my own covenant with you, and you are to enter the ark—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons' wives.
6.19: You are to bring two of every living thing into the ark so they may remain alive with you. They are to be male and female.
6.20: From birds according to their species, from domestic animals according to their species, and from everything that crawls on the ground according to their species —two of everything will come to you so they may remain alive.
6.21: For your part, take some of the edible food and store it away—these stores will be food for you and the animals."
6.22: Noah did all of this, precisely as God had commanded.

7.1: Then the LORD told Noah, "Come—you and all your household—into the ark, because I've seen that you alone are righteous in this generation.
7.2: You are to take with you seven pairs of every clean animal, a male and its mate, and two of the unclean animals, a male and its mate;
7.3: along with seven pairs of the flying birds, male and female, in order to keep their offspring alive on the surface of all the earth.
7.4: Seven days from now I'll send rain on the earth for 40 days and 40 nights, and I'll destroy every living creature that I've made."
7.5: Noah did everything that the LORD commanded.
7.6: Noah was 600 years old when water began to flood the earth.
7.7: Noah, his sons, his wife, and his sons' wives entered the ark with him before the flood waters arrived.
7.8: From both clean and unclean animals, from birds, and from everything that crawls on the ground,
7.9: two by two, male and female, they entered the ark to join Noah, just as God had commanded.
7.10: Seven days later, the flooding started.
7.11: On the seventeenth day of the second month, when Noah was 600 years old, all the springs of the great deep burst open, the floodgates of the heavens were opened,
7.12: and it rained throughout the earth for 40 days and 40 nights.
7.13: On that very day, Noah entered the ark with his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, Noah's wife, his sons' three wives with them,
7.14: along with every species of wild animal, livestock, crawling creature, bird, and every creature that has wings.
7.15: Two of each living creature entered the ark with Noah.
7.16: The males and females of each living creature entered the ark, just as God had commanded. Then the LORD sealed them inside.
7.17: The flood continued throughout the earth for 40 days, while the flood waters increased, lifting the ark so that it rose above the surface of the earth.
7.18: The flood waters continued to surge, increasing throughout the earth, while the ark floated on the surface of the flood water.
7.19: The flood water surged even higher throughout the earth, until all the highest mountains under the sky were covered.
7.20: The flood waters rose 15 cubits above the mountains.
7.21: Every living thing on earth died—flying creatures, livestock, wildlife, all creatures that swarm over the earth, and all human beings.
7.22: Everything that breathed and everything that had lived on dry land died.
7.23: All existing creatures that had lived on the surface of the ground were annihilated, from humans to livestock, from crawling creatures to birds of the sky. They were wiped off the earth. Only Noah remained, along with those who were with him in the ark.
7.24: The flood waters surged over the earth for 150 days.

8.1: God kept Noah in mind, along with all the wildlife and livestock that were with him in the ark. God's Spirit moved throughout the earth, causing the flood waters to subside.
8.2: The water sources from the ocean depths were blocked and the floodgates of the heavens were closed.
8.3: Then the flood waters steadily receded, diminishing completely by the end of the 150 days.
8.4: The ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat on the seventeenth day of the seventh month.
8.5: The flood water continued to recede until the tenth month, when, on the first of that month, the tops of the mountains could be seen.
8.6: After 40 days, Noah opened the window of the ark that he had built
8.7: and sent out a raven. It went back and forth as the flood water continued to evaporate throughout the earth.
8.8: Later, he sent a dove out from the ark to see whether the water that covered the land's surface had completely receded,
8.9: but the dove could not yet find a place to rest, so it returned to Noah on the ark, since water still covered the land. Noah reached out his hand and took the dove back into the ark with him.
8.10: Noah waited another seven days and sent the dove out from the ark again.
8.11: The dove returned to him in the evening, but in its beak there was an olive leaf that it had plucked! So Noah knew that the flood waters had decreased on the land.
8.12: He waited seven more days and sent the dove out again, but it did not return to him anymore.
8.13: In the six hundred and first year of Noah's life, during the first month, the flood water began to evaporate from the land. Noah then removed the ark's cover and saw that the surface of the land was drying.
8.14: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month, the ground was dry.
8.16: "It's time for you, your wife, your sons, and your sons' wives who are with you to leave the ark.
8.17: Bring out with you every living creature—including the flying creatures, animals, and everything that crawls on the ground—so they may disperse throughout the land, be fruitful, and multiply throughout the earth."
8.18: So Noah, his sons, his wife, and his sons' wives emerged.
8.19: Every animal, every crawling thing, every flying creature, and everything that moves on the earth emerged from the ark by groups.
8.20: Then Noah built an altar to the LORD and offered burnt offerings on it from every clean animal and every clean bird.
8.21: When the LORD smelled the pleasing aroma, he told himself, "I will never again curse the land because of human beings—even though human inclinations remain evil from youth—nor will I destroy every living being ever again, as I've done.
8.22: "Never again, as long as the earth exists, will sowing and harvest, cold and heat, summer and winter, and day and night ever cease."

9.1: God blessed Noah and his sons and ordered them, "Be productive, multiply, and fill the earth.
9.2: All the living creatures of the earth will be filled with fear and terror of you from now on, including all the creatures that fly in the sky, everything that crawls on the ground, and all the fish of the ocean. They've been assigned to live under your dominion.
9.3: "Every living, moving creature will be food for you. Just as I gave you green plants before, so now you have everything.
9.4: However, you are not to eat meat with its life—that is, its blood—in it!
9.5: Also, I will certainly demand an accounting regarding bloodshed, from every animal and from every human being. I'll demand an accounting from every human being for the life of another human being.
9.6: "Whoever sheds human blood, by a human his own blood is to be shed; because God made human beings in his own image.
9.7: Now as for you, be productive and multiply; spread out over the land and multiply throughout it."
9.8: Later, God told Noah and his sons,
9.9: "Pay attention! I'm establishing my covenant with you and with your descendants after you,
9.10: and with every living creature that is with you—the flying creatures, the livestock, and all the wildlife of the earth that are with you—all the earth's animals that came out of the ark.
9.11: I will establish my covenant with you: No living beings will ever be cut off again by flood waters, and there will never again be a flood that destroys the earth."
9.12: God also said, "Here's the symbol that represents the covenant that I'm making between me and you and every living being with you, for all future generations:
9.13: I've set my rainbow in the sky to symbolize the covenant between me and the earth.
9.14: Whenever I bring clouds over the earth and the rainbow becomes visible in the clouds,
9.15: I'll remember my covenant between me and you and every living creature, so that water will never again become a flood to destroy all living beings.
9.16: When the rainbow is in the clouds, I will observe it and remember the everlasting covenant between God and all living beings on the earth."
9.17: God also told Noah, "This is the symbol of the covenant that I've established between me and everything that lives on the earth."
9.18: Noah's sons who came out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. (Ham later fathered Canaan.)
9.19: These three were Noah's sons, and from these men the whole earth was repopulated.
9.20: Noah, a man of the soil, was the first to plant and farm a vineyard.
9.21: He drank some of the wine, got drunk, and lay down naked right in the middle of his tent.
9.22: Ham, who fathered Canaan, saw his father's genitals and told his two brothers outside.
9.23: Then Shem and Japheth took their father's cloak, laid it across both their shoulders, and walking backwards, they both covered their father's genitals. Their faces were turned away, and they did not see their father's genitals.
9.24: When Noah sobered up and learned what his youngest son had done to him,
9.25: he said, "Canaan is cursed! He will be the lowest of slaves to his relatives."
9.26: He also said, "Blessed be the LORD God of Shem, and may Canaan be his slave.
9.27: May God make room for Japheth; may God live in Shem's tents, and may Canaan serve him."
9.28: Noah lived 350 years after the flood.
9.29: After Noah had lived a total of 950 years, he died.

10.1: These are the records of Noah's sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, to whom descendants were born after the flood.
10.2: Japheth's descendants included Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
10.3: Gomer's descendants included Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
10.4: Javan's descendants included Elisha, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim,
10.5: from whom the coastal peoples spread into their own lands and nations, each with their own language and family groups.
10.6: Ham's descendants included Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
10.7: Cush's descendants included Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. Raamah's descendants included Sheba and Dedan.
10.8: Cush fathered Nimrod, who became the first fearless leader throughout the land.
10.9: He became a fearless hunter in defiance of the LORD. That is why it is said, "Like Nimrod, a fearless hunter in defiance of the LORD."
10.10: His kingdom began in the region of Shinar with the cities of Babylon, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh.
10.11: From there he went north to Assyria and built Nineveh, Rehoboth-ir, and Calah,
10.12: along with Resen, which was located between Nineveh and the great city of Calah.
10.13: Egypt fathered the Ludites, the Anamites, the Lehabites, the Naphtuhites,
10.14: the Pathrusites, the Casluhites (from which came the Philistines), and the Caphtorites.
10.15: Canaan fathered Sidon his firstborn, along with the Hittites,
10.16: the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
10.17: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
10.18: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites. Later, the Canaanite families were widely scattered.
10.19: The Canaanite border extended south from Sidon toward Gerar as far as Gaza, and east toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha.
10.20: These are Ham's descendants, listed by their families, each with their own lands, language, and family groups.
10.21: Shem, Japheth's older brother, also had descendants. Shem was the father of the descendants of Eber.
10.22: Shem's sons included Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram.
10.23: Aram's descendants included Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
10.24: Arpachshad fathered Cainan, Cainan fathered Shelah, and Shelah fathered Eber.
10.25: To Eber were born two sons. One was named Peleg, because the earth was divided during his lifetime. His brother was named Joktan.
10.26: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
10.29: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were Joktan's descendants.
10.30: Their settlements extended from Mesha towards Sephar, the eastern hill country.
10.31: These are Shem's descendants, listed by their families, each with their own lands, language, and family groups.
10.32: These are the families of Noah's sons, according to their records, by their nations. From these people, the nations on the earth spread out after the flood.

11.1: There was a time when the entire earth spoke a common language with an identical vocabulary.
11.2: As people migrated westward, they came across a plain in the region of Shinar and settled there.
11.3: They told each other, "Come on! Let's burn bricks thoroughly." They used bricks for stone and tar for mortar.
11.4: Then they said, "Come on! Let's build ourselves a city and a tower, with its summit in the heavens, and let's make a name for ourselves so we won't be scattered over the surface of the whole earth."
11.5: However, the LORD descended to look over the city and the tower that the humans were building.
11.6: The LORD said, "Look! They are one people with the same language for all of them, and this is only the beginning of what they will do. Nothing that they have a mind to do will be impossible for them!
11.7: Come on! Let's go down there and confuse their language, so that they won't understand each other's speech."
11.8: So the LORD scattered them abroad from there over the surface of the whole earth, so that they had to stop building the city.
11.9: Therefore it was called Babylon, because there the LORD confused the language of all the earth, and from there the LORD scattered them over the surface of the entire earth.
11.10: These are the family records of Shem. When Shem had lived 100 years, he fathered Arpachshad two years after the flood.
11.11: Shem lived 500 years after he fathered Arpachshad and had other sons and daughters.
11.12: When Arpachshad had lived 35 years, he fathered Cainan.
11.13: After he fathered Cainan, Arpachshad lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters, and then died. Cainan lived 130 years and fathered Shelah. After he fathered Shelah, Cainan lived 330 years and had other sons and daughters, and then died.
11.14: When Shelah had lived 30 years, he fathered Eber.
11.15: After he fathered Eber, Shelah lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.16: When Eber had lived 34 years, he fathered Peleg.
11.17: After he fathered Peleg, Eber lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.18: When Peleg had lived 30 years, he fathered Reu.
11.19: After he fathered Reu, Peleg lived 209 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.20: When Reu had lived 32 years, he fathered Serug.
11.21: After he fathered Serug, Reu lived 207 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.22: When Serug had lived 30 years, he fathered Nahor.
11.23: After he fathered Nahor, Serug lived 200 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.24: When Nahor had lived 29 years, he fathered Terah.
11.25: After he fathered Terah, Nahor lived 119 years and had other sons and daughters.
11.26: When Terah had lived 70 years, he fathered Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
11.27: Now these are the family records of Terah: Terah fathered Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran fathered Lot.
11.28: Haran died during his father's lifetime in the land of his birth, that is, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
11.29: Abram and Nahor took wives for themselves. The name of Abram's wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor's wife was Milcah. She was the daughter of Haran, who was the father of Milcah and Iscah.
11.30: Sarai was barren, so she had not borne children.
11.31: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot (Haran's son), and his daughter-in-law Sarai, his son Abram's wife, and they journeyed together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the land of Canaan. But when they had gone as far as Haran, they settled there,
11.32: where Terah died at the age of 205 years.

12.1: The LORD told Abram, "You are to leave your land, your relatives, and your father's house and go to the land that I'm going to show you.
12.2: I'll make a great nation of your descendants, I'll bless you, and I'll make your reputation great, so that you will be a blessing.
12.3: I'll bless those who bless you, but I'll curse the one who curses you, and through you all the people of the earth will be blessed."
12.4: So Abram left there, as the LORD had directed him, and Lot accompanied him. Abram was 75 years old when he left Haran.
12.5: Abram took his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, all the possessions they had accumulated, and the servants he had acquired while living in Haran. Then they set out to go to the land of Canaan. When they arrived in the land of Canaan,
12.6: Abram traveled through the land to the place called Shechem, as far as the oak of Moreh. At that time the Canaanites were in the land.
12.7: Then the LORD appeared to Abram and said, "I'll give this land to your descendants." So Abram built an altar to the LORD, who had appeared to him.
12.8: From there Abram traveled on to the hill country east of Bethel and set up his tent, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. There he built an altar to the LORD and called on the name of the LORD.
12.9: Then Abram traveled on, continuing into the Negev.
12.10: There was a famine in the land, so Abram went down to Egypt to live because the famine was so severe.
12.11: When he was about to enter Egypt, he told his wife Sarai, "Look, I'm aware that you're a beautiful woman.
12.12: When the Egyptians see you, they will say, 'She is his wife.' Then they'll kill me, but allow you to live.
12.13: Please say that you are my sister, so things will go well for me for your sake. That way, you'll be saving my life."
12.14: As Abram was entering Egypt, the Egyptians noticed how beautiful Sarai was.
12.15: When Pharaoh's officials saw her, they brought her to the attention of Pharaoh and took the woman to Pharaoh's palace.
12.16: He treated Abram well because of her, so Abram acquired sheep, oxen, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.
12.17: But the LORD afflicted Pharaoh and his household with severe plagues because of Sarai, Abram's wife.
12.18: Pharaoh summoned Abram and asked, "What have you done to me! Why didn't you tell me that she was your wife?
12.19: Why did you say, 'She is my sister,' so that I took her as a wife for myself? Now, here is your wife! Take her and get out!"
12.20: So Pharaoh assigned men to Abram, and they escorted him, his wife, and all that he had out of the country.

13.1: Abram traveled from Egypt, along with his wife and everyone who belonged to his household —including Lot—to the Negev.
13.2: Now Abram had become quite wealthy in livestock, silver, and gold.
13.3: He journeyed by stages from the Negev to Bethel, the place where his tent had formerly been, between Bethel and Ai,
13.4: where he had first built an altar. There Abram called on the name of the LORD.
13.5: Lot, who was traveling with Abram, also had flocks of sheep, herds, and tents.
13.6: But the land could not support them living together, because they had so many livestock that they could not stay together.
13.7: There was strife between the herdsmen in charge of Abram's livestock and the herdsmen in charge of Lot's livestock. Also, at that time the Canaanites and the Perizzites were living in the land.
13.8: So Abram told Lot, "Please, let's not have strife between you and me, or between your herdsmen and my herdsmen, since we are relatives.
13.9: Isn't the whole land available to you? Let's separate: If you go to the left, then I will go to the right; if you go to the right, then I will go to the left."
13.10: Lot looked around and noticed that the whole Jordan plain as far as Zoar was well-watered like the garden of the LORD or like the land of Egypt. (This was before the LORD destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)
13.11: So Lot chose for himself all the Jordan plain. Then Lot traveled eastward, and they separated from each other.
13.12: So Abram lived in the land of Canaan, while Lot settled in the cities of the plain, setting up his tent in the vicinity of Sodom.
13.13: Now the men of Sodom were particularly evil and sinful in their defiance of the LORD.
13.14: After Lot had separated from Abram, the LORD told Abram, "Look off to the north, south , east, and west from where you're living,
13.15: because I'm going to give you and your descendants all of the land that you see—forever!
13.16: I'll make your descendants as plentiful as the specks of dust of the earth, so that if one could count the specks of dust of the earth, then your descendants could also be counted.
13.17: Get up! Walk throughout the length and breadth of the land, because I'm going to give it to you."
13.18: So Abram moved his tent and settled beside the oaks of Mamre that are by Hebron, where he built an altar to the LORD.

14.1: At the time when Amraphel was king of Shinar, Arioch was king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer was king of Elam, and Tidal was king of the Goiim,
14.2: they engaged in war against King Bera of Sodom, King Birsha of Gomorrah, King Shinab of Admah, King Shemeber of Zeboiim, along with the king of Bela (which was also known as Zoar).
14.3: All of this latter group of kings allied together in the Valley of Siddim (that is, the Salt Sea ).
14.4: They were subject to Chedorlaomer for twelve years, but they rebelled in the thirteenth year.
14.5: In the fourteenth year, Chedorlaomer and the kings with him came and defeated the Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, the Emites in Shaveh-kiriathaim,
14.6: and the Horites in the hill country of Seir, near El-paran by the desert.
14.7: Next they turned back and came to En-mishpat (which was also known as Kadesh) and conquered all the territory of the Amalekites, along with the Amorites who lived in Hazazon-tamar.
14.8: Then the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Bela (which was also known as Zoar) prepared for battle in the Valley of Siddim
14.9: against King Chedorlaomer of Elam, King Tidal of Goiim, King Amraphel of Shinar, and King Arioch of Ellasar—four kings against five.
14.10: Now the Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits, so when the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some of their people fell into them, while the rest fled to the hill country.
14.11: The conquerors captured all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah, including their entire food supply, and then left.
14.12: They also took Abram's nephew Lot captive, and confiscated his possessions, since he was living in Sodom.
14.13: Someone escaped, arrived, and reported what had happened to Abram the Hebrew, who was living by the oaks belonging to Mamre the Amorite, whose brothers Eshcol and Aner were allied with Abram.
14.14: When Abram heard that his nephew had been taken prisoner, he gathered together 318 of his trained men, who had been born in his household, and they went out in pursuit as far as Dan.
14.15: During the night, Abram and his servants divided his forces, conquered his enemies, and pursued them as far as Hobah, north of Damascus.
14.16: He recovered all the goods and brought back his nephew Lot, together with his possessions, the women, and the other people.
14.17: After Abram's return from defeating Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with them, the king of Sodom went out to meet with him in the Shaveh Valley (that is, the King's Valley).
14.18: King Melchizedek of Salem brought out bread and wine, since he was serving as the priest of God Most High.
14.19: Melchizedek blessed Abram and said, "Abram is blessed by God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
14.20: and blessed be God Most High, who has delivered your enemies into your control." Then Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
14.21: The king of Sodom told Abram, "Return the people to me, and you take the possessions for yourself."
14.22: But Abram answered the king of Sodom, "I have made an oath to the LORD God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
14.23: that I will not take a thread or a sandal strap or anything that belongs to you, so you won't be able to say, 'I made Abram rich.'
14.24: I will take nothing except what my warriors have eaten. But as for what belongs to the men who were allied with me, including Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre, let them take their share."

15.1: Some time later, a message came from the LORD to Abram in a vision: "Don't be afraid, Abram. I am your shield. Your reward will be very great."
15.2: But Abram replied, "Lord GOD, what can you give me since I continue to be childless, and the heir of my household is Eliezer from Damascus?
15.3: Look!" Abram said, "You haven't given me any offspring, so a servant born in my house is going to be my heir."
15.4: A message came from the LORD to him again: "This one will not be your heir. Instead, the child who will be born to you will be your heir."
15.5: Then the LORD took him outside. "Look up at the sky and count the stars—if you can!" he said. "Your descendants will be that numerous."
15.6: Abram believed the LORD, and it was credited to him as righteousness.
15.7: The LORD spoke to him, "I am the LORD, who brought you from Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you this land as an inheritance."
15.8: But he replied, "Lord GOD, how will I know that I will inherit it?"
15.9: The LORD responded, "Bring me a three-year-old cow, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon."
15.10: So Abram brought him all these animals and cut each of them in half, down the middle, placing the pieces opposite each other, but he did not cut the birds in half.
15.11: When birds of prey swooped down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
15.12: As the sun began to set, Abram was overcome with deep sleep, and suddenly a frightening and terrifying darkness descended on him.
15.13: Then the LORD told Abram, "You can be certain about this: Your descendants will be foreigners in a land that isn't theirs. They will be slaves there and will be oppressed for 400 years.
15.14: However, I will judge the nation that they serve, and later they will leave there with many possessions.
15.15: Now as for you, you'll die peacefully, join your ancestors, and be buried at a good old age.
15.16: Your descendants will return here in the fourth generation, since the iniquity of the Amorites has not yet run its course."
15.17: When the sun had fully set and it was dark, a smoking fire pot and a fiery torch passed between the animal pieces.
15.18: That very day the LORD made this covenant with Abram: "I'm giving this land to your descendants, from the river of Egypt to the great Euphrates River—
15.19: including the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites,
15.20: the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaim,
15.21: the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites."

16.1: Now Abram's wife Sarai had not borne a child for him. She had an Egyptian servant girl whose name was Hagar.
16.2: So Sarai told Abram, "You are well aware that the LORD has prevented me from giving birth to a child. Go have sex with my servant, so that I may possibly bear a son through her." Abram listened to Sarai's suggestion,
16.3: so Abram's wife Sarai took her Egyptian servant, Hagar, and gave her as a wife to her husband Abram. This took place ten years after Abram had settled in the land of Canaan.
16.4: He had sex with Hagar, and she became pregnant. When she realized that she was pregnant, she looked with contempt on her mistress.
16.5: Then Sarai told Abram, "My suffering is your fault! I gave you my servant so you could have sex with her , and when she discovered that she was pregnant, she looked on me with contempt. May the LORD judge between you and me!"
16.6: Abram answered Sarai, "Look, your servant is under your control, so do to her as you wish." So Sarai dealt so harshly with Hagar that she ran away from Sarai.
16.7: The angel of the LORD found her by a spring of water in the desert on the road to Shur.
16.8: "Hagar, servant of Sarai," he asked, "Where are you coming from and where are you going?" She answered, "I am running away from my mistress Sarai."
16.9: The angel of the LORD told her, "You must go back to your mistress and submit to her authority."
16.10: The angel of the LORD also told her, "I will greatly multiply your offspring, who will be too many to count.
16.11: "Look, you are pregnant and will give birth to a son," the angel of the LORD continued to say to her. "You will name him Ishmael, because the LORD has heard your cry of misery.
16.12: He'll be a wild donkey of a man. He'll be against everyone, and everyone will be against him. He will live in conflict with all of his relatives."
16.13: So she called the name of the LORD who spoke to her, "You are 'God who sees,' because I have truly seen the one who looks after me."
16.14: That's why the spring was called, "The Well of the Living One who Looks after Me." It was between Kadesh and Bered.
16.15: Hagar eventually gave birth to Abram's son. Abram named his son whom Hagar bore Ishmael.
16.16: Abram was 86 years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael for Abram.

17.1: When Abram was 99 years old, the LORD appeared to Abram and announced, "I am God Almighty. Live in constant awareness that I'm always with you, and be blameless.
17.2: I'll establish my covenant between me and you, and I'll greatly increase your numbers."
17.3: Then Abram fell to the ground as God continued speaking to him.
17.4: "Look, I've made a covenant with you. You will be the father of many nations.
17.5: Your name is no longer to be Abram. Instead your name will be Abraham, since I'll make you the father of many nations.
17.6: I'm going to cause you to have many descendants, and I'll bring nations from you. Kings will come from you.
17.7: I'm establishing my covenant between me and you, and with your descendants who come after you, generation after generation, as an eternal covenant, to be your God and your descendants' God after you.
17.8: I'll give to you and to your descendants the land to which you have traveled—all the land of Canaan—as an eternal possession. I will be their God."
17.9: God continued to speak to Abraham, "You and your descendants who are born in the future are to keep my covenant—that is, you and your descendants, generation after generation.
17.10: Here is my covenant that you are to observe, between me and you and your descendants: Every male among you is to be circumcised.
17.11: You are all to be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin, and this is to be the sign of the covenant between me and you.
17.12: Generation after generation, every male among you is to be circumcised on the eighth day after his birth, including the servant born in your house or the one purchased from a foreigner, who is not of your offspring.
17.13: The servant born in your house or the one purchased with money is to be circumcised. My covenant is to remain in your flesh as an eternal covenant.
17.14: Any uncircumcised male who does not have the foreskin of his flesh circumcised on the eighth day after his birth is to be eliminated from his people because he has broken my covenant."
17.15: God told Abraham, "As for Sarai your wife, you are not to call her Sarai any longer, because her name is to be Sarah.
17.16: I will bless her. Furthermore, I will give you a son from her. I will bless her, so that nations, kings, and people will come from her."
17.17: Abraham fell to the ground, laughed, and told himself, "Can a child be born to a 100-year-old man? Can a 90-year-old Sarah give birth?"
17.18: So Abraham responded to God, "If only Ishmael would live in constant awareness that you're always with him!"
17.19: But God replied, "No, but your wife Sarah will give birth to your son, and you are to name him Isaac. I'll confirm my covenant with him as an eternal covenant for his descendants.
17.20: And as for Ishmael, I've heard you. I'll bless him, and he'll have many descendants. I will multiply him greatly, he'll father twelve tribal leaders, and I'll cause his descendants to become a great nation.
17.21: Now as to Isaac, I'll confirm my covenant with him, to whom Sarah will give birth as your son at this time next year."
17.22: With that, God finished talking to Abraham, and ascended, leaving him.
17.23: Abraham took his son Ishmael and all the servants born in his house or purchased with his money—every male among the men of his household—and circumcised them that very day, just as God had spoken to him.
17.24: Abraham was 99 years old when he was circumcised,
17.25: and his son Ishmael was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.
17.26: Both Abraham and his son Ishmael were circumcised on that very day.
17.27: Every man born in his household—as well as those who had been purchased with money from a foreigner—was circumcised with him.

18.1: Later, the LORD appeared to Abraham by the oaks belonging to Mamre. As Abraham was sitting near the entrance to his tent during the hottest part of the day,
18.2: he glanced up and saw three men standing there, not far from him. As soon as he noticed them, Abraham ran from the tent entrance to greet them and bowed low to the ground.
18.3: "My lords," he told them, "if I have found favor with you, please don't leave your servant.
18.4: I'll have some water brought to wash your feet while you rest under the tree.
18.5: I'll bring some food for you, and after that you may continue your journey, since you have come to visit your servant." So they replied, "Okay! Do what you've proposed."
18.6: Abraham hurried into the tent and told Sarah, "Quick! Take three measures of the best flour, knead it, and make some flat bread."
18.7: Next, Abraham ran to the herd, found a choice and tender calf, and gave it to the young men, who went off in a hurry to prepare it.
18.8: Then he took curds, milk, and the calf that had been prepared, placed the food in front of them, and stood near them under the tree while they ate.
18.9: The men asked him, "Where is your wife Sarah?" "There, in the tent," he replied.
18.10: Then one of them said, "I will certainly return to you in about a year's time. By then, your wife Sarah will have borne a son." Now Sarah was listening at the tent entrance behind him.
18.11: Abraham and Sarah were old—really old —and Sarah was beyond the age of childbearing.
18.12: That's why Sarah laughed to herself, thinking, "After I'm so old and my husband is old, too, am I going to have sex?"
18.13: The LORD asked Abraham, "Why did Sarah laugh and think, 'Am I really going to bear a child, since I'm so old?'
18.14: Is anything impossible for the LORD? At the time set for it, I will return to you—about a year from now—and Sarah will have a son."
18.15: But Sarah denied it. "I didn't laugh," she claimed, because she was afraid. The LORD replied, "No! You did laugh!"
18.16: After this, the men set out from there and looked out over Sodom. Abraham went with them to send them off.
18.17: "Should I hide from Abraham what I'm about to do," the LORD asked,
18.18: "since Abraham's descendants will become a great and powerful nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed through him?
18.19: Indeed, I've made myself known to him in order that he may encourage his sons and his household that is born after him to keep the way of the LORD, and to do what is right and just, so that the LORD may bring about for Abraham what he has promised."
18.20: The LORD also said, "How great is the disapproval of Sodom and Gomorrah! Their sin is so very serious!
18.21: I'm going down to see whether they've acted according to the protests that have reached me. If not, I wish to know."
18.22: Then two of the men turned away from there and walked toward Sodom, while Abraham remained standing in the presence of the LORD.
18.23: Abraham approached and asked, "Will you actually destroy the righteous along with the wicked?
18.24: Perhaps there are 50 righteous ones within the city. Will you actually destroy it and not forgive the place for the sake of the 50 righteous that are found there?
18.25: Far be it from you to do such a thing—to kill the righteous along with the wicked, so that the righteous and the wicked are treated alike! The Judge of all the earth will do what is right, won't he?"
18.26: The LORD said, "If I find 50 righteous people within Sodom, I'll forgive the whole place for their sake."
18.27: Abraham answered, "Look, even though I am only dust and ashes, I've ventured to speak to my LORD.
18.28: What if there are five less than 50 righteous ones? Will you bring destruction upon the city because of those five?" The LORD said, "I won't destroy it if I find 45 there."
18.29: Abraham continued to speak to him, asking, "What if 40 are found there?" The LORD replied, "I won't do it for the sake of those 40."
18.30: Abraham then asked, "I hope my LORD will not be angry if I speak. What if 30 are found there?" The LORD answered, "I won't do it for the sake of those 30."
18.31: "Look," Abraham said, "I've presumed to speak to my LORD… so what if 20 are found there?" "For the sake of those 20," the LORD responded, "I won't destroy it."
18.32: Finally, Abraham inquired, "I hope my LORD will not be angry if I speak only once more. What if ten are found there?" He replied, "For the sake of those ten I won't destroy it."
18.33: As soon as he finished talking to Abraham, the LORD left and Abraham returned to where he had been sitting.

19.1: The two angels entered Sodom at sunset while Lot was sitting in the gate area of the city. When Lot saw them, he got up, greeted them, bowed low with his face to the ground,
19.2: and said, "Look, my lords! Please come inside your servant's house, wash your feet, and spend the night. Then you can get up early and be on your way." But they responded, "No, we would rather spend the night in the town square."
19.3: But Lot kept urging them strongly, so they turned aside and entered his house. He prepared a festival and baked unleavened flat bread for them, and they ate.
19.4: Before they could lie down, all the men of Sodom and its outskirts, both young and old, surrounded the house.
19.5: They called out to Lot and asked, "Where are the men who came to visit you tonight? Bring them out to us so we can have sex with them!"
19.6: Lot went outside to them, shut the door behind him,
19.7: and said, "I urge you, my brothers, don't do such a wicked thing.
19.8: Look here, I have two daughters who are virgins. Let me bring them out to you, and you may do to them whatever you wish, only don't do anything to these men, because they're here under my protection."
19.9: But they replied, "Get out of the way! This man came here as a foreigner, and now he's acting like a judge! So we're going to deal more harshly with you than with them." Then they pushed hard against the man (that is, against Lot), intending to break down the door.
19.10: But the angels inside reached out, dragged Lot back into the house with them, shut the door,
19.11: and blinded the men who were at the entrance of the house, from the least important to the greatest, so they were unable to find the doorway.
19.12: "Do you have anyone else here in the city?" the angels asked Lot. "A son-in-law? Sons? Daughters? Get them out of this place,
19.13: because we're going to destroy it. The LORD knows how their behavior stinks, so he sent us here to destroy it!"
19.14: Lot then went out and told his sons-in-law (they had married his daughters), "Get out of here! The LORD is going to destroy this city!" But his sons-in-law thought he was joking.
19.15: As dawn was breaking, the angels pressured Lot. "Get going!" they told him. "Take your wife and your two daughters who are here, or you will be engulfed by the devastation that's coming to this city."
19.16: But Lot kept lingering in the city, so the men grabbed his hand and the hands of his wife and two daughters (because of the LORD's compassion for him!), brought them out of the city, and left them outside.
19.17: Then one of them said, "Flee for your lives! Don't look back or stop anywhere on the plain. Escape to the hills, or you'll be swept away!"
19.18: "No! Please, my lords!" Lot pleaded with them.
19.19: "Your servant has found favor in your sight, and you have shown me your gracious love in how you have dealt with me by keeping me alive. I cannot escape to the hills, because I'm afraid the disaster will overtake me, and I'll die.
19.20: Look, there is a town nearby where I can flee, and it's a small one. Let me escape there! It's a small one, isn't it? That way I'll stay alive!"
19.21: "All right," the angel replied to Lot, "I'll agree with your request! I won't overthrow the town that you mentioned.
19.22: Hurry up and flee there, because I cannot do anything until you get to that town." Therefore the name of the town was called Zoar.
19.23: The sun had risen over the land about the time Lot reached Zoar.
19.24: Then the LORD rained sulfur and fire out of the sky from the LORD on Sodom and Gomorrah,
19.25: overthrowing those cities, all of the plain, and everyone who lived in the cities. He also destroyed the plants that grew out of the ground.
19.26: But Lot's wife looked back as she lingered behind him, and she became a pillar of salt.
19.27: Abraham went early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the LORD earlier.
19.28: He looked off toward Sodom, Gomorrah, and the entire plain, and he saw smoke rising from the land like smoke from a furnace.
19.29: And so it was that, when God destroyed the cities of the plain, he remembered Abraham and brought Lot out from the midst of the destruction when he overthrew the cities where Lot had lived.
19.30: Later on, Lot and his two daughters abandoned Zoar and settled in the hills because Lot was afraid to live in Zoar. He lived there in a cave, along with his two daughters.
19.31: One day the firstborn told the younger one, "Our father is old, and there's no man in the land to have sex with us, as everybody else throughout all the earth does.
19.32: Come on! Let's make our father drink wine, and then we'll have sex with him so we can preserve our father's lineage."
19.33: So they had their father drink wine that night, and the older one had sexual relations with her father, but he was not aware when she lay down or when she got up.
19.34: The next day the firstborn told the younger one, "Look! I had sex with my father last night. Let's make him drink wine tonight again as well. Then you have sex with him, too. That way we'll preserve our father's lineage."
19.35: So they made their father drink wine that night as well, so he was not aware when she lay down or when she got up.
19.36: That's how both of Lot's daughters became pregnant by their father.
19.37: The firstborn gave birth to a son and named him Moab, and he is the ancestor of the Moabites to this day.
19.38: The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben-ammi, and he is the ancestor of the Ammonites to this day.

20.1: Abraham traveled from there to the Negev and settled between Kadesh and Shur. While he was living in Gerar as an outsider,
20.2: because Abraham kept saying about his wife Sarah, "She is my sister," King Abimelech of Gerar summoned them and took Sarah into his household.
20.3: But God came to Abimelech in a dream during the night and spoke to him, "Pay attention! You're about to die, because the woman you have taken is a man's wife!"
20.4: Now Abimelech had not yet come near her, so he asked, "LORD, will you destroy an innocent nation?
20.5: Didn't he say to me, 'She's my sister'? And she also said, 'He's my brother.' I did this with pure intentions and clean hands."
20.6: Then God replied to him in the dream, "I know that you did this with pure intentions, and it was I who kept you from sinning against me. Therefore, I didn't allow you to touch her.
20.7: Now then, return the man's wife. As a matter of fact, he's a prophet and can intercede for you so you'll live. But if you don't return her, be aware that you and all who are yours will certainly die."
20.8: So Abimelech got up early the next morning, summoned all his servants, and told them all these things. The men became terrified.
20.9: Then Abimelech called Abraham and asked him, "What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you, that you have brought such great sin against me and my kingdom? You've done things to me that ought not to have been done."
20.10: Abimelech also asked Abraham, "What could you have been thinking when you did this?"
20.11: "I thought that there's no fear of God in this place," Abraham replied, "and that they would kill me because of my wife.
20.12: Besides, she really is my sister—she's my father's daughter, but not my mother's daughter—so she could become my wife.
20.13: When God caused me to journey from my father's house, I asked her to do me this favor and say, 'He's my brother.'"
20.14: So Abimelech took some sheep and oxen, and some male and female servants, gave them to Abraham, returned his wife Sarah to him,
20.15: and said, "Look! My land is available to you, so settle wherever you please."
20.16: Abimelech also told Sarah, "Look! I am giving your brother 1,000 pieces of silver to vindicate you in the eyes of all who are with you. As a result, you will be completely vindicated."
20.17: Then Abraham interceded with God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female servants so they could bear children,
20.18: since the LORD had made all the women barren in Abimelech's household on account of Abraham's wife Sarah.

21.1: The LORD came to Sarah, just as he had said, and the LORD did for Sarah what he had promised.
21.2: Sarah conceived and gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age, at the very time that God had told him.
21.3: Abraham named his son who was born to him Isaac—the very one whom Sarah bore for him!
21.4: On the eighth day after his son Isaac had been born, Abraham circumcised him, just as God had commanded him.
21.5: Abraham was 100 years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
21.6: Now Sarah had said, "God has caused me to laugh, and all who hear about it will laugh with me."
21.7: She also said, "Who would have told Abraham that Sarah would nurse sons? Yet I have given birth to a son in my husband's old age!"
21.8: The child grew and eventually was weaned, so Abraham threw a tremendous banquet on the very day Isaac was weaned.
21.9: Nevertheless, when Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian—whom Hagar had borne to Abraham—making fun of Isaac,
21.10: she told Abraham, "Throw out this slave girl, along with her son, because this slave's son will never be a co-heir with my son Isaac!"
21.11: Abraham was very troubled about what was being said about his son,
21.12: but God told Abraham, "Don't be troubled about the youth and your slave girl. Pay attention to Sarah in everything she tells you, because your offspring are to be named through Isaac.
21.13: Nevertheless, I will make the slave girl's son into a nation, since he, too, is your offspring."
21.14: So early the next morning, Abraham got up, took bread and a leather bottle of water, gave them to Hagar, and placed them on her shoulder. He then sent her away, along with the child. She went off and roamed in the Beer-sheba wilderness.
21.15: Eventually, the water in the leather bottle ran out, so she placed the child under one of the bushes.
21.16: Then she went and sat by herself about a distance of a bowshot away, because she kept saying to herself, "I can't bear to watch the child die!" That's why she sat a short distance away, crying aloud and weeping.
21.17: God heard the boy's voice, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven. He asked her, "What's wrong with you, Hagar? Don't be afraid, because God has heard the voice of the youth where he is.
21.18: Get up! Pick up the youth and grab his hand, because I will make a great nation of his descendants."
21.19: Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water. So she went, filled the skin with water, and gave the boy a drink.
21.20: God was with the boy as he grew up. He settled in the wilderness and became an expert archer.
21.21: Later he settled in the desert area of Paran, and his mother chose a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
21.22: About that time, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, told Abraham, "God is with you in everything that you're doing.
21.23: Therefore swear an oath here by God that you won't deal falsely with me, my sons, or my descendants. Just as I've dealt graciously with you, won't you do so with me and with the land in which you live as a foreigner?"
21.25: But then Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water that Abimelech's servants had seized.
21.26: "I don't know who did this thing," Abimelech replied. "You didn't report this to me, and I didn't hear about it until today."
21.27: So Abraham took sheep and oxen and presented them to Abimelech, and the two of them made a covenant.
21.28: Then Abraham set aside seven ewe lambs,
21.29: so Abimelech asked Abraham, "What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs that you have set aside?"
21.30: He replied, "You are to accept from me these seven ewe lambs as a witness that I have dug this well."
21.31: Therefore that place was called Beer-sheba, because the two of them swore an oath.
21.32: So after they had made a covenant in Beer-sheba, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, left and returned to Philistine territory.
21.33: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beer-sheba, and there he called on the name of the LORD God Everlasting.
21.34: After this, Abraham resided as a foreigner in Philistine territory for a long period of time.

22.1: Sometime later, God tested Abraham. He called out to him, "Abraham!" "Here I am!" he answered.
22.2: God said, "Please take your son, your unique son whom you love—Isaac—and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him as a burnt offering there on one of the mountains that I will point out to you."
22.3: So Abraham got up early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his male servants with him, along with his son Isaac. He cut the wood for the burnt offering and set out to go to the place about which God had spoken to him.
22.4: On the third day he looked ahead and saw the place from a distance.
22.5: Abraham ordered his two servants, "Both of you are to stay here with the donkey. Now as for the youth and me, we'll go up there, we'll worship, and then we'll return to you."
22.6: Then Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and placed it on his son Isaac. Abraham carried the fire and the knife. And so the two of them went on together.
22.7: Isaac addressed his father Abraham: "My father!" "I'm here, my son," Abraham replied. Isaac asked, "The fire and the wood are here, but where's the lamb for the burnt offering?"
22.8: Abraham answered, "God will provide himself the lamb for the burnt offering, my son." The two of them went on together
22.9: and came to the place about which God had spoken. Abraham built an altar there, arranged the wood, tied up his son Isaac, and placed him on the altar on top of the wood.
22.10: Then he stretched out his hand and grabbed the knife to slaughter his son.
22.11: Just then, an angel of the LORD called out to him from heaven and said, "Abraham! Abraham!" "Here I am," he answered.
22.12: "Don't lay your hand on the youth!" he said. "Don't do anything to him, because I've just demonstrated that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only unique one, from me."
22.13: Then Abraham looked up and behind him to see a ram caught by its horns in the thicket. So Abraham went over, grabbed the ram, and offered it as a burnt offering in place of his son.
22.14: Abraham named that place, "The LORD Will Provide," as it is told this day, "On the LORD's mountain, he will provide."
22.15: The angel of the LORD called to Abraham a second time from heaven
22.16: and said, "I have taken an oath to swear by myself," declares the LORD, "that since you have carried this out and have not withheld your only unique son,
22.17: I will certainly bless you and make your descendants as numerous as the stars in heaven and as the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of the gates of their enemies.
22.18: Furthermore, through your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed my command."
22.19: After this, Abraham returned to his servants and they set out together for Beer-sheba, where Abraham settled.
22.20: Now after these things somebody told Abraham, "Look, Milcah has given birth to sons for your brother Nahor.
22.21: Uz is his firstborn, Buz is his brother, and Kemuel is the father of Aram,
22.22: Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel."
22.23: Bethuel fathered Rebekah. Milcah bore these eight sons to Nahor, Abraham's brother.
22.24: Also, his concubine Reumah gave birth to Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.

23.1: Sarah lived for 127 years. That's how long Sarah's life was.
23.2: She died in Kiriath-arba (that is, in Hebron) in the land of Canaan. Abraham went in to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
23.3: Then Abraham stood up from beside his dead wife and addressed the Hittites. He said,
23.4: "I am an alien and an outsider among you. Give me a cemetery among you where I can bury my dead away from my presence."
23.6: "Listen to us, sir. You are a mighty prince among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our burial tombs. None of us would refuse you his tomb for burying your dead."
23.7: Abraham rose and bowed before the Hittites, the people of the land,
23.8: and addressed them, "If you are willing that I should bury my dead out of my sight, listen to me and make a request of Zohar's son Ephron on my behalf.
23.9: Give me the cave of Machpelah that belongs to him, at the end of his field. He should sell it to me in your presence at full price for a burial site."
23.10: Now since Ephron the Hittite had taken a seat there among the Hittites, he responded publicly to Abraham where the Hittites and everyone who was entering the gate of his city could hear him:
23.11: "No, sir. Listen to me! I'll give you the field, and I'll give you the cave that's in it. I give it to you publicly, in the sight of my people. Bury your dead."
23.12: Abraham bowed before the people of the land
23.13: and then addressed Ephron so all the people of the land could hear him: "Please listen to me! I'm willing to pay the price of the field. Accept it from me, so I may bury my dead there."
23.15: "Sir, listen to me! The land is worth 400 shekels of silver, but what's that between us? You may bury your dead."
23.16: Abraham agreed with Ephron, so he weighed out to Ephron the money to which he had agreed publicly while the Hittites were listening: 400 shekels of silver at the current merchant rate.
23.17: That's how Ephron's field in Machpelah, east of Mamre—the field, the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were within the boundaries of the field—came to be deeded
23.18: to Abraham in the presence of all the Hittites and everyone who was entering the city gate.
23.19: After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave at the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre (that is, in Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
23.20: And so the field with its cave was deeded by the Hittites to Abraham as a burial site.

24.1: Now Abraham had grown old, was well advanced in age, and the LORD had blessed Abraham in every way.
24.2: So Abraham instructed his servant, who was the oldest member of his household and in charge of everything he owned, "Make this solemn oath to me
24.3: as a promise to the LORD, the God of heaven and earth, that you won't acquire a wife for my son from the Canaanite women among whom I'm living.
24.4: Instead, you are to go to my country and to my family and acquire a wife for my son Isaac."
24.5: "What if the woman doesn't want to come back with me to this land?" the servant asked. "Shouldn't I have your son go to the land from which you came?"
24.6: "Make sure not to take my son there," Abraham replied.
24.7: "The LORD God of heaven, who brought me from my father's house and from my family's land, who spoke to me and promised me 'I will give this land to your descendants,' will send his angel ahead of you, and you are to acquire a wife for my son from there.
24.8: If the woman isn't willing to follow you, then you'll be free from this oath to me. Just don't take my son back there!"
24.9: So the servant made a solemn oath to his master Abraham regarding this matter.
24.10: Then Abraham's servant took ten camels from his master's herd of camels and left on his journey with all kinds of gifts from his master's inventory. Eventually, he traveled as far as Aram-naharaim, Nahor's home town.
24.11: As evening approached, he had the camels kneel outside the town at the water well, right about the time when women customarily went out to draw water.
24.12: That's when he prayed, "LORD God of my master Abraham, help me to succeed today. Please show your gracious love to my master Abraham.
24.13: I've stationed myself here by the spring as the women of the town come to draw water.
24.14: May it be that the young woman to whom I ask, 'Please, lower your jug so that I may drink,' responds, 'Have a drink, and I'll water your camels as well.' May she be the one whom you have chosen for your servant Isaac. This is how I'll know that you have shown your gracious love to my master."
24.15: Before he had finished speaking, Rebekah appeared. She was a daughter of Milcah's son Bethuel. (Milcah was the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor.) She approached the well, carrying a jug on her shoulder.
24.16: The woman was very beautiful, young, and had not had sexual relations with a man. Going down to the spring, she filled her jug and turned for home.
24.17: Then Abraham's servant ran to meet her and asked her, "Please, let me have a sip of water from your jug."
24.18: "Drink, sir!" she replied as she quickly lowered her jug on her arm to offer him a drink.
24.19: When she had finished giving him a drink, she also said, "I'll also draw water for your camels until they've had enough to drink."
24.20: She quickly emptied her jug into the trough and ran to the well to draw again until she had drawn enough water for all ten of the servant's camels.
24.21: The man stared at her in silence, waiting to see whether or not the LORD had made his journey successful.
24.22: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing a half shekel and two bracelets for her wrists, weighing 10 shekels and presented them to her.
24.23: He asked her, "Whose daughter are you? Please tell me, is there room in your father's house for us to spend the night?"
24.24: "I am the daughter of Bethuel," she answered. "He's the son of Milcah and Nahor.
24.25: And yes," she continued, "we have plenty of straw and feed, as well as a place to spend the night."
24.26: At this, the man bowed down and worshipped the LORD.
24.27: "Blessed be the LORD God of my master Abraham, who hasn't held back his gracious love and faithfulness from my master! The LORD has led me to the house of my master's relatives!"
24.28: The young woman then ran ahead and informed her mother's household what had happened.
24.29: Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, who ran out to the man and met him at the spring.
24.30: And so it was, as soon as he saw the nose ring and bracelets on his sister's wrists, and as soon as he heard what his sister Rebekah was saying about what the man had spoken to her, he went out to the man who was still standing by the camels at the spring!
24.31: "Come on," Laban said. "The LORD has blessed you! So why are you standing out here when I've prepared some space in the house and a place for the camels?"
24.32: So the servant went to the house and unbridled the camels. They provided straw and feed for the camels and water for washing his feet and those of the men with him.
24.33: But when they had prepared a meal and set it in front of him, he said, "I'm not eating until I've spoken." "Speak up!" Laban exclaimed.
24.35: "The LORD has greatly blessed my master, so that he has become wealthy. He has provided him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels and donkeys.
24.36: My master's wife Sarah gave birth to my master's son in her old age, and Abraham has given him everything that belongs to him.
24.37: My master made me swear this oath: 'You are not to select a wife for my son from among the daughters of the Canaanites in this land where I live.
24.38: Instead, you are to go to my father's household, to my relatives, and choose a wife for my son there.'
24.39: "So I asked my master, 'What if the woman won't come back with me?'
24.40: "Abraham told me, 'The LORD, who is with me wherever I go, will send his angel with you to make your journey successful. So you are to choose a wife for my son from my family, from my father's household.
