13.58: Then the clothing (whether it is woven or knitted material) or any article made of leather that you've washed, if the contagion has been removed from it and it's washed a second time, then it's clean.
13.59: "This is the law concerning fungal contagions on clothing of wool or linen (whether woven or knitted material) or in any of the articles made of leather, for determining whether it is clean or unclean."

14.2: "This is the law concerning those who have infectious skin diseases, after they have been cleansed:
14.3: The priest is to go outside the camp and examine the infectious skin disease to confirm that the person has been healed.
14.4: If he has been healed, then the priest is to command that two live and clean birds, some cedar wood, some crimson thread, and hyssop be brought for the one cleansed.
14.5: Then the priest is to command that one bird be slaughtered on an earthen vessel over flowing water.
14.6: He is to take the live bird, the cedar wood, the crimson thread, and the hyssop, and dip them together in the blood of the bird that had been slaughtered over the flowing water.
14.7: He is to sprinkle the blood seven times on the person with the infectious skin disease and then pronounce him clean. Then he is to release the live bird into the open fields.
14.8: The person who is clean is to wash his clothes, shave all his hair, and bathe in water, after which he is to be declared clean. Then he can be brought back to the camp, but he is to remain outside his tent for seven days.
14.9: On the seventh day, he is to shave the hair on his head, chin, back, and eyebrows. After he has shaved all his hair, washed his clothes, and bathed himself with water, then he will be clean."
14.10: "On the eighth day, he is to take two lambs without defect, a one year old ewe lamb without defect, one third of a measure of fine flour mixed with olive oil for a meal offering, and one log of oil.
14.11: The priest who will pronounce him clean is to present the person to be cleansed and these offerings in the LORD's presence at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
14.12: The priest is to take one of the lambs and present it as a guilt offering, along with one log of olive oil, which he is to wave as a raised offering in the LORD's presence.
14.13: Then he is to slaughter the lamb in the place where he slaughtered the sin and burnt offerings—that is, at a place in the sanctuary. Just as the sin offering is for the priest, so also is the guilt offering. It's a most holy thing.
14.14: "Then the priest is to take some of the blood from the guilt offering and place it on the right earlobe of the person to be cleansed, on his right thumb, and on his right great toe.
14.15: Then the priest is to take some of the log of olive oil and pour it into his own left hand.
14.16: The priest is to dip his right finger in the olive oil that is in his left palm and sprinkle some of the olive oil with his finger seven times in the LORD's presence.
14.17: "As to the remainder of the olive oil in his palm, he is to place some on the right earlobe of the person to be cleansed, on his right thumb, on his right great toe, and on the blood of the guilt offering.
14.18: Then he is to place the rest of the oil in his palm on the head of the person to be cleansed, thus making atonement for him in the LORD's presence.
14.19: This is how the priest is to present the sin offering to make atonement for the person being cleansed of his impurity. After this, he is to slaughter the whole burnt offering.
14.20: The priest is to offer both the whole burnt and the grain offerings on the altar. After the priest makes atonement for him, he will be clean."
14.21: "If the offeror is poor and cannot afford the regular offering, then he is to take one lamb for a guilt offering that will be presented in the form of a wave offering to atone for him, one tenth of a measure of fine flour mixed with olive oil for a grain offering, one log of olive oil,
14.22: and two turtledoves or two young pigeons, whichever he can afford. One is for a sin offering and the other is for a whole burnt offering.
14.23: "On the eighth day, he is to bring them for cleansing to the priest in the LORD's presence at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
14.24: The priest is to take the lamb for a guilt offering and the olive oil and wave them as a raised offering in the LORD's presence.
14.25: Then he is to take the lamb for the guilt offering and place some blood from the guilt offering on the right earlobe of the person to be cleansed, on his right thumb, and on his right great toe.
14.26: Then the priest is to pour olive oil into his left palm
14.27: and use his right finger to sprinkle oil from his left palm seven times in the LORD's presence.
14.28: The priest is to place oil from his palm on the right earlobe of the person being cleansed, on his right thumb, on his right great toe, and where the blood for the guilt offering is poured.
14.29: "As to the remainder of the oil in his palm, the priest is to use it to anoint the head of the person to be cleansed, in order to make atonement for him in the LORD's presence.
14.30: Then he is to offer one of the turtledoves or the young pigeons, whichever he can afford.
14.31: Based on what he can afford, one is for a sin offering and the other is for a whole burnt offering. Along with the grain offering, the priest is to make atonement for the person to be cleansed in the LORD's presence.
14.32: This is the regulation concerning one who has an infectious skin disease but who cannot afford his cleansing."
14.33: The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron:
14.34: "When you enter the land of Canaan that I'm about to give you as your own possession, and if I put a contagion in a house in the land that you possess,
14.35: then the owner of the house is to approach the priest and tell him, 'There appears to be a contagion in the house.'
14.36: "The priest is to command that the house be cleared before he comes to examine the contagion so that not everything in the house becomes unclean. After this, the priest is to enter the house and examine it.
14.37: He is to determine if the contagion is indeed on the walls of the house, with greenish or reddish streaks, and to determine if it appears to be deeper than the surface of the wall.
14.38: The priest is to leave through the entrance to the house and seal the house for seven days.
14.39: He is to return after seven days to examine it. If the contagion has spread to the walls of the house,
14.40: then the priest is to command that they take out the contaminated stones and discard them in an unclean place outside the city.
14.41: "Now as for the house, they are to scrape off inside and outside the house and then discard the torn out plaster in an unclean place outside the city.
14.42: They are then to take other stones and bring them to replace those stones. Lastly, they are to replaster the house."
14.43: "If the contagion returns and spreads throughout the house after the stones have been removed, after the house has been scraped out, and after it has been re-coated,
14.44: and the priest comes, undertakes an examination, and determines that the contagion has spread in the house, it's a chronic fungal infection in the house. It's unclean.
14.45: He is to pull down the house, its stones, its lumber, and all the plaster on the house, and discard them in an unclean place outside the city.
14.46: Moreover, whoever enters the house during the time it was isolated is to be considered unclean until the evening.
14.47: Whoever has slept in the house is to wash his clothes, along with whoever has eaten in the house.
14.48: "But if the priest comes in to conduct an examination and determines that the contagion has not spread throughout the house after the house has been repaired, then the priest may declare the house clean, because the contagion has been cleansed.
14.49: In order to cleanse the house, he is to take two birds, some cedar wood, two crimson threads, and some hyssop.
14.50: Then he is to slaughter one bird on an earthen vessel over flowing water.
14.51: He is to take the cedar wood, the hyssop, the two crimson threads, and the live bird, and dip them in the blood of the slaughtered bird over flowing water. Then he is to sprinkle the house seven times.
14.52: He is to clean the house with the blood of the bird over flowing water, including cleansing the live bird, the cedar wood, the hyssop, and the crimson thread.
14.53: Then he is to send the bird away, outside the city, facing the fields, to make atonement for the house. Then it is to be considered clean.
14.54: "This is the law for every contagion of infectious skin disease and scabs,
14.55: for fungal infections on clothing or in a house,
14.56: and for swelling of the skin, scabs, and bright spots,
14.57: to distinguish when it's unclean and clean. This is the law for infectious skin diseases."

15.1: The LORD told Moses and Aaron,
15.2: "Tell the Israelis that when a man has a discharge from his body, his discharge is unclean,
15.3: and this is the cause of his uncleanness—his discharge. Whether his body is releasing the discharge or his body has stopped the discharge, he's unclean.
15.4: Every bed on which he lies down with the discharge is to be considered unclean, and every object on which he sits becomes unclean.
15.5: Any person who touches his bed is to wash his garments and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.6: Whoever sits on any object on which the one with the discharge has sat is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.7: "Whoever touches the body of someone with a discharge is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.8: Whoever has a discharge and spits on someone who is clean, then he is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.9: "Any saddle that anyone with a discharge rides on will become unclean.
15.10: Whoever touches anything that was under him will be unclean until evening. Whoever carries these things is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.11: "Anyone whom the one with the discharge touches without rinsing his hands with water is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.12: The earthen vessel that the person with the discharge touches is to be broken in pieces, and every wooden vessel is to be rinsed with water."
15.13: "When the one with the discharge is cleansed from his discharge, then he is to set aside for himself seven days for his cleansing. He is to wash his clothes and bathe with flowing water. Then he will be clean.
15.14: On the eighth day, he is to take for himself two turtledoves or two young doves, bring them to the LORD at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, and give them to the priest.
15.15: Then the priest is to offer them—one for a sin offering and the other for a whole burnt offering. That's how the priest will make atonement for him in the LORD's presence regarding his discharge."
15.16: "If a man has a seminal emission, he is to bathe his entire body with water and remain unclean until evening.
15.17: Every garment (including leather) on which the semen is found is to be washed with water, and it will remain unclean until evening.
15.18: When a man has sexual relations with a woman and the man releases semen, both are to bathe with water, and they will remain unclean until evening."
15.19: "When a woman has a discharge, and the blood is her monthly menstrual discharge from her body, then for seven days she is to remain in her menstrual uncleanness. Whoever touches her will remain unclean until evening.
15.20: Everything that she sleeps on during her uncleanness will be unclean. Moreover, everything that she sits on will become unclean.
15.21: Anyone who touches her bed is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.22: Anyone who touches any of the objects on which she has sat is to wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.23: Any bed or other object on which she sat that he touches will make him unclean until evening.
15.24: When a man has sexual relations with her and her menstrual uncleanness touches him, he will be unclean for seven days. Every bed where he sleeps will remain unclean.
15.25: "When a woman has a continuous discharge of blood many days beyond the time of her menstrual uncleanness, or if she has a discharge that lasts beyond the days of her menstrual uncleanness, her uncleanness is to be treated like the days of her menstruation—she's unclean.
15.26: Every bed on which she sleeps the whole time she has the discharge will be her own unclean bed, so that every object on which she sits becomes unclean like her menstrual uncleanness.
15.27: Whoever touches them will become unclean. He is to wash his clothes and bathe with water and he will remain unclean until evening.
15.28: "If she becomes clean with her discharge, then she is to count for herself seven days, after which she becomes clean.
15.29: On the eighth day, she is to take for herself two turtledoves or two young pigeons and bring them to the priest at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
15.30: Then the priest is to offer one for a sin offering and the other for a whole burnt offering. This is how the priest will make atonement in the LORD's presence for her regarding her unclean discharge.
15.31: "So separate the Israelis from their uncleanness so that they won't die in their uncleanness if they defile my tent that is in their midst.
15.32: These are the regulations for one whose discharge of semen causes him to become unclean because of it,
15.33: for her whose menstruation causes her to become ill, for anyone who has a discharge (whether male or female), and for the man who has sexual relations with one who is unclean."

16.1: The LORD spoke to Moses after the death of Aaron's two sons when they had approached the LORD and died.
16.2: The LORD told Moses, "Remind your brother Aaron that at no time is he to enter the sacred place from the room that contains the curtain into the presence of the Mercy Seat on top of the ark. Otherwise, he'll die, because I will appear in a cloud at the Mercy Seat.
16.3: Aaron is to enter the sacred place with a young bull for a sin offering and a ram for a whole burnt offering.
16.4: He is to wear a sacred linen tunic and linen undergarments that will cover his genitals. He is to clothe himself with a sash and wrap his head with a linen turban. Because they are sacred garments, he is to wash himself with water before putting them on."
16.5: "He is to take two male goats for a sin offering and one ram for a whole burnt offering from the assembly of the Israelis.
16.6: Then Aaron is to bring the bull as a sin offering for himself and make atonement for himself and his household.
16.7: Then he is to take the two male goats and present them in the LORD's presence at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
16.8: Aaron is to cast lots over the two male goats—one lot for the LORD and the other one for the scapegoat.
16.9: Aaron is then to bring the male goat on which the lot fell for the LORD and offer it as a sin offering.
16.10: The male goat on which the lot fell for the scapegoat is to be brought alive into the LORD's presence to make atonement for himself. Then he is to send it into the wilderness."
16.11: "Aaron is then to bring the bull for a sin offering for himself, thus making atonement for himself and his household. He is to slaughter the ox for himself.
16.12: Then he is to take a censer and fill it with coals from the fire on the altar in the LORD's presence. With his hands full of spiced and refined incense, he is to bring it beyond the curtain.
16.13: "Then he is to place the incense over the fire in the LORD's presence, ensuring that the smoke from the incense covers the Mercy Seat, according to regulation, so he won't die.
16.14: He is to take blood from the ox and sprinkle it with his forefinger toward the surface of the Mercy Seat. Then he is to sprinkle the blood on the surface of the Mercy Seat with his forefinger seven times.
16.15: "He is to slaughter the male goat as a sin offering for the people and bring its blood beyond the curtain and do with its blood as he did with the blood of the bull: He is to sprinkle it on the Mercy Seat—that is, over the surface of the Mercy Seat.
16.16: Then he is to make atonement on the sacred place on account of the uncleanness of the Israelis, their transgressions, and all their sins. This is how he is to act in the Tent of Meeting, which will remain with them in the middle of their uncleanness.
16.17: "No person is to be there when he enters the Tent of Meeting to make atonement in the sacred place, until he comes out and has made atonement on account of himself, his household, and the entire assembly of Israel.
16.18: When he goes to the altar in the LORD's presence to make atonement for himself, he is to take some of the blood from the bull and the male goat, place it around the horns of the altar,
16.19: and sprinkle it with the blood on his forefinger seven times, cleansing and sanctifying it from Israel's sins."
16.20: "When he has completed making atonement at the sacred place, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, then he is to present the live male goat.
16.21: Aaron is to lay his two hands upon the head of the male goat and confess over it the sins of Israel, all their transgressions, and all their sins, thus placing them on the head of the male goat that he'll then send out to the wilderness by the hand of a man capable of carrying out this task.
16.22: The male goat will bear on itself all their sins to a solitary land as Aaron sends the goat out to the wilderness.
16.23: "Then Aaron is to enter the Tent of Meeting, take off his white linen clothes that he had put on when he entered the sacred place, and leave them there.
16.24: He is to wash his body with water at the sacred place and put on his clothes. Then he is to go out and offer a whole burnt offering for himself and a whole burnt offering for the people, thereby making atonement on account of himself and on account of the people.
16.25: "As to the fat from the burnt offering, he is to incinerate it on the altar.
16.26: The one who sent away the male goat as a scapegoat is to wash his clothes and bathe his body with water. After doing so, he may enter the camp.
16.27: "The bull for the sin offering and the male goat for the sin offering, whose blood was brought into the sacred place, are to be taken outside the camp. Their skin, meat, and offal are to be incinerated.
16.28: The one who burns them is to wash his clothes and bathe his body with water. After doing so, he may enter the camp."
16.29: "This is to be a perpetual statute for you: On the tenth day of the seventh month, you (including both the native born and the resident alien) are to humble yourselves by not doing any work,
16.30: because on that day, atonement will be made for you to cleanse you from all your sins. You are to be clean in the LORD's presence.
16.31: It's the Sabbath of all Sabbaths for you, so humble yourselves. This is to be a perpetual statute.
16.32: The priest who has been anointed and consecrated to be priest after his father is to make the atonement. He is to put on the sacred linen clothing
16.33: and make atonement for the sacred sanctuary, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar where atonement is carried out. He is also to make atonement for the priests and the people of the entire assembly.
16.34: This will be a perpetual statute for you as you make atonement once a year for the Israelis on account of all their sins." So Moses did just as the LORD had commanded him.

17.2: "Speak to Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelis and tell them that this is what the LORD has commanded:
17.3: When a person from the house of Israel slaughters an ox, a lamb, or a goat (whether in the camp or outside the camp),
17.4: but fails to bring it to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting as an offering in the presence of the tent of the LORD, that person will incur bloodguilt. Because he has shed blood, that person is to be eliminated from contact with his people."
17.5: "This statute is required so that the Israelis may bring their sacrifices that they have been sacrificing to the LORD in the open field to the priest at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, where they are to slaughter their peace offering to the LORD.
17.6: The priest is to sprinkle the blood on the LORD's altar at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting and incinerate the fat, making a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
17.7: They are no longer to slaughter their sacrifices to the goat demons, with whom they have been committing prostitution. This will be a perpetual statute for you throughout your generations.
17.8: Tell them that if a person from the house of Israel or a resident alien who lives among you brings a whole burnt offering or a sacrifice
17.9: to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, but fails to bring it to offer it to the LORD, that person is to be eliminated from contact with his people."
17.10: "If anyone from the house of Israel or a resident alien who lives among you eats any form of blood, I'll oppose that person who ate the blood and eliminate him from his people,
17.11: because the life of the flesh is in the blood itself, and I myself have given it to you all so that atonement may be made for your souls on the altar, since the blood itself makes atonement through the life that is in it.
17.12: This is why I've told the Israelis that no person among you is to eat blood. Even the resident alien who lives among you is not to eat blood.
17.13: "If a person from the house of Israel or a resident alien who lives among you has hunted live game or a bird that may be eaten, he is to extract its blood and cover it with soil,
17.14: because the life of any flesh is the blood itself. Therefore, I'm saying to the Israelis that the blood of any flesh is not to be eaten, because the life of any flesh is in its blood. Anyone who eats of it is to be eliminated from contact with his people.
17.15: "Any person who eats a carcass or an animal that was torn by beasts (whether that person is native born or is a resident alien), is to wash his clothes and bathe himself with water, and he will remain unclean until evening, and then he'll become clean.
17.16: But if he doesn't wash or bathe his body, then he is to bear the punishment of his iniquity."

18.2: "Tell the Israelis that I am the LORD your God.
18.3: You are not to do what you used to do in the land of Egypt where you lived. You are not to do what Canaan does, where I'm about to bring you, so that you live according to their statutes.
18.4: Obey my ordinances and keep my statutes by living by them. I am the LORD your God.
18.5: Keep my statutes and my ordinances, which a person is to obey in order to live in them. I am the LORD.
18.6: "A person is not to approach a near blood relative for sexual relations. I am the LORD.
18.7: "Neither your father's nakedness nor your mother's nakedness is to be exposed. She's your mother, so you are not to have sexual relations with her.
18.8: "You are not to have sexual relations with your father's wife. It's your own father's nakedness.
18.9: "You are not to have sexual relations with your sister, whether she's your father's daughter or your mother's daughter, whether she's born in your home or outside your home. You are not to have sexual relations with her.
18.10: "You are not to have sexual relations with your son's daughter or your daughter's daughter. You are not to have sexual relations with them, because their nakedness is your own nakedness.
18.11: "You are not to have sexual relations with the daughter of your father's wife. Born of your father, she's your sister, so you are not to have sexual relations with her.
18.12: "You are not to have sexual relations with your father's sister. She's your father's near blood relative.
18.13: "You are not to have sexual relations with your mother's sister. She's your mother's near blood relative.
18.14: "You are not to expose the nakedness of your father's brother by having sexual relations with his wife. She's your aunt.
18.15: "You are not to expose the nakedness of your daughter-in-law. She's the wife of your son. You are not to have sexual relations with her.
18.16: "You are not to have sexual relations with your brother's wife. She's the nakedness of your brother.
18.17: "You are not to have sexual relations with a woman and her daughter. "You are not to have sexual relations with her son's daughter or her daughter's daughter. They're near blood relatives. It's wickedness.
18.18: "You are not to marry a woman and then have sexual relations with her sister as a rival when your wife is still alive.
18.19: "You are not to approach a menstruating woman to have sexual relations with her.
18.20: "You are not to have sexual relations with your neighbor's wife and thereby become ceremonially unclean with her."
18.21: "You are not to present any of your children to Molech as a sacrifice. That way, you won't defile the name of your God." "I am the LORD.
18.22: You are not to have sexual relations with a male as you would with a woman. It's detestable."
18.23: "You are not to present yourself to an animal in order to have sexual relations with it and by doing so to defile yourself. A woman is not to present herself to an animal to have sexual relations with it. It's detestable.
18.24: "You are not to defile yourselves by doing any of these things, since all of these nations that I'm casting out before you have defiled themselves this way.
18.25: The land has been defiled, so I brought the punishment of its iniquity to it. As a result, the land is vomiting out its inhabitants.
18.26: "Therefore, keep my statutes and ordinances. You are not to do any of these detestable things—this applies to the native born and the resident alien who lives among you—
18.27: because the inhabitants of the land did all of these detestable things and by doing so defiled the land before you.
18.28: So you are not to let the land vomit you up because of your uncleanness as it is vomiting the nations that were here before you.
18.29: Anyone who does any of these detestable things—whoever the person may be—is to be eliminated from contact with his people.
18.30: Therefore, keep my injunctions so that you won't practice these detestable things that have been done before you, and so that you won't be defiled in them. I am the LORD."

19.2: "Tell the entire assembly of Israel that they are to be holy, since I, the LORD your God, am holy.
19.3: "Each of you is to fear his mother and father. "Observe my Sabbaths. I am the LORD your God.
19.4: "You are not to turn to their idols or cast gods out of melted metal for yourselves. I am the LORD your God.
19.5: "When you offer a peace offering to the LORD, you are to offer it for your acceptance.
19.6: Your sacrifice is to be eaten on that day and the next day. Anything that remains to the third day is to be incinerated.
19.7: If it is eaten on the third day, it's unclean. It won't be accepted.
19.8: Anyone who eats it will bear the punishment of his sin, since he will have defiled himself regarding the LORD's holy things. That person is to be eliminated from contact with his people."
19.9: "When you reap the harvest of your land, you are not to completely finish harvesting the corners of the field—that is, you are not to pick what remains after you have reaped your harvest.
19.10: You are not to gather your vineyard or pick up the fallen grapes of your vineyard. Leave something for the poor and the resident alien who lives among you. I am the LORD your God."
19.11: "You are not to steal or lie or deal falsely with your neighbor.
19.12: "You are not to use my name to deceive, thereby defiling the name of your God. I am the LORD.
19.13: "You are not to oppress your neighbor or rob him. "The wages of a hired laborer are not to remain in your possession until morning.
19.14: "You are not to curse a deaf person or put a stumbling block before the blind. "You are to fear God. I am the LORD.
19.15: "You are not to be unjust in deciding a case. You are not to show partiality to the poor or honor the great. Instead, decide the case of your neighbor with righteousness."
19.16: "You are not to go around slandering your people. "You are not to stand idle when your neighbor's life is at stake. I am the LORD.
19.17: "You are not to hate your relative in your heart. Rebuke your neighbor if you must, but you are not to incur guilt on account of him.
19.18: "You are not to seek vengeance or hold a grudge against the descendants of your people. Instead, love your neighbor as yourself. I am the LORD."
19.19: "Observe my statutes. "You are not to let your cattle breed with a different species. "You are not to sow your fields with two different kinds of seeds. "You are not to wear clothing made from two different kinds of material.
19.20: "When a person has sexual relations with a woman servant who is engaged to another man, but she has not been completely redeemed nor has her freedom been granted to her, there is to be an inquiry, but they won't be put to death, since she has not been freed.
19.21: The perpetrator is to bring his guilt offering to the LORD at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting—that is, a ram as a guilt offering.
19.22: Then the priest is to make atonement for him with the ram as a guilt offering in the LORD's presence on account of his sin which he has committed, but which will be forgiven him."
19.23: "When you have entered the land and planted all sorts of trees for food, regard its fruit as uncircumcised for the first three years for you. It is not to be eaten.
19.24: During the fourth year, all its fruit is to be offered as a holy token of praise to the LORD.
19.25: But on the fifth year, you may eat its fruits to increase its produce for you."
19.26: "You are not to eat anything containing blood, engage in occult practices, or practice fortune telling.
19.27: "You are not to cut your hair in ritualistic patterns on your head or deface the edges of your beard.
19.28: "You are not to make incisions in your flesh on account of the dead nor submit to cuts or tattoos. I am the LORD.
19.29: "You are not to defile your daughter by engaging her in prostitution so the land won't become filled with wickedness.
19.30: "Observe my Sabbath and stand in awe of my sanctuary. I am the LORD.
19.31: "You are to consult neither mediums nor familiar spirits. You are never to seek them—you'll just be defiled by them. I am the LORD your God.
19.32: "Rise in the presence of the aged and honor the elderly face-to-face. "Fear your God. I am the LORD.
19.33: "If a resident alien lives with you in your land, you are not to mistreat him.
19.34: You are to treat the resident alien the same way you treat the native born among you—love him like yourself, since you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
19.35: "You are not to act unjustly in deciding a case or when measuring weight and quantity.
19.36: You are to maintain just balances and reliable standards for weights, dry volumes, and liquid volumes. I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
19.37: Observe all my statutes and all my ordinances in order to practice them. I am the LORD."

20.2: "Tell the Israelis that when an Israeli or a resident alien who lives in Israel offers his child to Molech, he is certainly to be put to death. The people who live in the land are to stone him with stones.
20.3: As for me, I'll oppose that man. I'll eliminate him from contact with his people for sacrificing his children to Molech, thereby defiling my sanctuary and profaning my holy name.
20.4: If the people avoid dealing with that man when he offers his child to Molech—that is, if they fail to execute him—
20.5: then I'll oppose that man and his family and eliminate him from contact with his people, along with all the prostitutes who accompany him and who have committed prostitution with Molech."
20.6: "I'll oppose and eliminate from contact with his people whoever consults mediums or familiar spirits, thereby committing spiritual prostitution with them.
20.7: Therefore, separate yourselves and be holy, because I am the LORD your God.
20.8: Keep my statutes and observe them. I am the LORD, who has set you apart."
20.9: "Anyone who curses his father or mother is certainly to be put to death. He has cursed his father or mother, so his guilt will remain his responsibility."
20.10: "If anyone commits adultery with another man's wife, including when someone commits adultery with his neighbor's wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress are to die.
20.11: "If a man has sexual relations with his father's wife, he has exposed his father's nakedness, so both of them are to be put to death. Their guilt will remain their responsibility.
20.12: "If a man has sexual relations with his daughter-in-law, the two are to be put to death. They've committed a repulsive act. Their guilt will remain their responsibility.
20.13: "If a man has sexual relations with another male as he would with a woman, both have committed a repulsive act. They are certainly to be put to death.
20.14: "If a man takes a wife along with her mother, that's wickedness. They are to be burned with fire—that is, both him and them, so that there will be no wickedness in your midst.
20.15: "If a man has sexual relations with an animal, he is to be put to death, and you are also to kill the animal.
20.16: "If a woman approaches any animal to have sexual relations with it, both the woman and the animal are to be put to death. Their guilt will remain their responsibility.
20.17: "If a man takes his sister, his father's daughter, or his mother's daughter, so that he exposes her nakedness and she exposes his nakedness, it's a shameful thing. They are to be eliminated from contact with their people in front of their people's children. He has exposed his sister's nakedness. He'll continue to bear responsibility for his iniquity.
20.18: "If a man has sexual relations with a menstruating woman, he has exposed her nakedness, laying bare her fountain. He has exposed the source of her blood. Both are to be eliminated from contact with their people.
20.19: "You are not to have sexual relations with your mother's sister or your father's sister, because that is laying bare the nakedness of his close relative. They'll continue to bear responsibility for their iniquity.
20.20: "If a man has sexual relations with his uncle's wife, he has exposed his uncle's nakedness. They are to bear responsibility for punishment of their sin. They'll die childless.
20.21: "If a man takes his brother's wife, it's immoral. He has exposed his brother's nakedness. They'll be childless."
20.22: "Be sure to keep all my statutes and observe all my ordinances, so that the land where I'm about to bring you to live won't vomit you out.
20.23: You are not to live by the customs of the nations, whom I've cast away right in front of you. Because they did all of these things, I detested them.
20.24: But I've promised you that you'll inherit the land that I'm about to give you as your permanent possession —a land flowing with milk and honey. "I am your God. I've separated you from the people.
20.25: You are to differentiate between the clean animal and the unclean and between the unclean bird and the clean. You are not to make yourselves detestable on account of any animal, bird, or any creeping creature of the ground that I've separated for you as unclean.
20.26: "You are to be holy toward me, because I, the LORD, am holy. I've separated you from among the people to be mine.
20.27: "Moreover, a man or a woman who has a ritual spirit or a familiar spirit is certainly to die. They are to be stoned to death with boulders. They will continue to bear responsibility for their guilt."

21.1: The LORD told Moses, "Speak to the priests, Aaron's sons, and tell them that no priest is to defile himself on account of the dead among his people,
21.2: except his close relatives—his mother, father, son, daughter, brother, or
21.3: virgin sister (who is a near relative of him and did not have a husband— he may defile himself for her).
21.4: Because he is a husband among his people, he is not to defile himself, thereby polluting himself.
21.5: "They are not to cut their hair in ritualistic patterns on their heads, deface the edges of their beards, or make incisions in their flesh.
21.6: They are to be holy to their God. They are not to defile the name of their God, because they're the ones who bring the offerings of the LORD made by fire—the food of their God—so they are to be holy.
21.7: "They are not to marry a prostitute or a woman who has been dishonored or who was divorced from her husband, because the priest is holy to his God.
21.8: Consecrate him, because he's the one who offers the food of your God. He is to be holy for you, because I, the LORD, the one who sanctifies you, am holy.
21.9: "Now if the daughter of any priest defiles herself by being a prostitute, she defiles her father. She is to be incinerated.
21.10: "The high priest among his relatives—whose head has been anointed with oil and who has been consecrated to put on the priestly clothing—is not to let his hair hang loose or to tear his clothes.
21.11: He is not to come near any dead body—whether the deceased is his father or his mother—so as not to defile himself.
21.12: He is not to go out of the sanctuary or defile the sanctuary of his God, because his God's consecrating oil of anointing rests on him. I am the LORD.
21.13: "Furthermore, he is to marry a true virgin.
21.14: He is not to marry a widow or one who has been divorced, has been defiled, or has been a prostitute. Instead, he is to take a virgin from among his people as his wife.
21.15: "He is not to defile his children among his people, because I am the LORD, who sets him apart."
21.17: "Tell Aaron that whoever of your descendants throughout their generations has a bodily defect is not to approach to offer the food of his God.
21.18: Indeed, any person who has a defect is not to approach the Tent of Meeting— the blind, the lame, one who is mutilated in the face or who has a very long limb,
21.19: or a person who has a fractured foot or hand,
21.20: has scoliosis, is a dwarf, or has an eye defect, an itching disease, scabs, or a crushed testicle.
21.21: None of the descendants of Aaron the priest who has a defect is to approach to bring offerings of the LORD made by fire, since he has a defect. He is not to approach to offer the food of his God.
21.22: However, he may eat the food of his God, including the most holy and the holy offerings,
21.23: but he is not to enter through the curtain nor approach the altar, since he has a defect. That way, he won't defile my sanctuary, since I am the LORD, who sets you apart."
21.24: Moses told all of this to Aaron, to his sons, and to all the Israelis.

22.1: Later on, the LORD told Moses,
22.2: "Tell Aaron and his sons that they are to separate themselves for the sacred things of the Israelis and that they are not to defile my holy name. I am the LORD.
22.3: Tell them that whoever among your descendants throughout your generations approaches the sacred things that the Israelis had consecrated to the LORD while still remaining unclean is to be eliminated from my presence. I am the LORD.
22.4: If one of Aaron's descendants has an infectious skin disease or a discharge, he is not to eat anything sacred until he has been cleansed. Anyone who touches an unclean thing on account of the dead, or who has a seminal discharge,
22.5: or who becomes unclean by touching a creeping creature or another human being, whatever the uncleanness may be—
22.6: such a person who comes in contact with anything like this will become unclean until evening. As a result, he is not to eat the sacred things unless he has bathed himself with water.
22.7: When the sun has gone down and he has been cleansed, he may eat of the sacred things, since that's his food.
22.8: He is not to eat the carcass of an animal that was torn by animals, thereby defiling himself with it. I am the LORD.
22.9: They are to keep my charge. By doing so, they won't bear the punishment of sin because of it and therefore die if they've been defiled by it. I am the LORD, who sets them apart."
22.10: "No resident alien is to eat anything sacred. Neither the visitor of the priest nor a hired laborer is to eat anything sacred.
22.11: If a priest acquires a slave as property with his own money, he may eat with him. Those who were born in his house may eat his food.
22.12: If a priest's daughter marries a resident alien, she is not to eat the sacred raised offerings.
22.13: If the priest's daughter is a widow, or is divorced and childless, so that she has to return to her father's house as in her younger days, she may eat her father's food, but no resident alien may eat it.
22.14: If a person eats anything sacred inadvertently, he is to add a fifth part to it and then give the sacred thing to the priest.
22.15: They are not to defile the sacred things of the Israelis that they have offered to the LORD,
22.16: thereby causing them to bear the punishment of their iniquity for wrongdoing when they eat their sacred things, because I am the LORD, who sets them apart."
22.18: "Tell Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelis that when a person from the house of Israel or from the resident aliens living in Israel brings his offering to the LORD as a whole burnt offering (whether in fulfillment of a promise or a free will offerings),
22.19: so that he'll be sure to be accepted, he is to offer a male without defect from the bulls, the lambs, and the goats.
22.20: However, whatever has a defect is not to be offered, because it won't be acceptable for you.
22.21: "If a person brings a peace offering sacrifice to the LORD to fulfill a vow or a free will offering from the herd or the flock, it is to be sound in order to be accepted, without any defect in it.
22.22: You are not to bring to the LORD an offering that is blind, fractured, mutilated, or infected with ulcers, scurvy, or scales. You are not to present any of them as an offering made by fire on the altar for the LORD.
22.23: "You may offer a bull or lamb that has one limb longer than the other or that is stunted as a free will offering, but it's not acceptable in fulfillment of a promise.
22.24: You are not to bring to the LORD an animal that has been emasculated, crushed, torn, or cut apart. You are not to practice this in your land.
22.25: A resident alien is not to offer as food to your God any of these items, because they are afflicted with ritual corruption due to their defects. They're not acceptable for you."
22.27: "Whenever a bull, a sheep, or a goat is born, it is to remain for seven days under the care of its mother. But on the eighth day onwards, it may be accepted as an offering made by fire to the LORD.
22.28: However, you are not to slaughter a bull or a ewe along with its offspring on the same day.
22.29: When you offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving to the LORD, bring it so that it's acceptable for you.
22.30: It is to be eaten that same day. You are not to leave any of it until morning. I am the LORD.
22.31: "Keep my commands and observe them. I am the LORD.
22.32: "You are not to defile my sacred name, because I've been set apart in the midst of the Israelis. Furthermore, I am the LORD, who sets you apart—
22.33: who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the LORD."

23.2: "Tell the Israelis that these are my festival times appointed by the LORD that you are to declare as sacred assemblies:
23.3: Six days you may work, but the seventh day is a Sabbath of rest, a sacred assembly. You are not to do any work. It's a Sabbath to the LORD wherever you live.
23.4: These are the LORD's appointed festivals and sacred assemblies that you are to declare at their appointed time.
23.5: "The LORD's Passover is to begin on the fourteenth day of the first month at twilight.
23.6: On the fifteenth day of that month is the Festival of Unleavened Bread to the LORD. For seven days you are to eat unleavened bread.
23.7: On the first day that you hold the sacred assembly, you are to do no servile work.
23.8: Instead, you are to bring an offering made by fire to the LORD daily for seven days. On the seventh day, you are also to hold a sacred assembly during which you are to do no servile work."
23.10: "Tell the Israelis that when you enter the land that I'm about to give you and gather its produce, you are to bring a sheaf from the first portion of your harvest to the priest,
23.11: who will offer the sheaf in the LORD's presence for your acceptance. The priest is to wave it on the day after the Sabbath.
23.12: On the day you wave the sheaf, you are to offer a one year old male lamb without defect for a burnt offering in the LORD's presence.
23.13: Also present a meal offering of two tenths of a measure of fine flour mixed with olive oil as an offering made by fire to the LORD, a pleasing aroma. Now as to a drink offering, you are to present a fourth of a hin of wine.
23.14: You are not to eat bread, parched grain, or fresh grain until that day when you've brought the offering of your God. This is to be an eternal ordinance throughout your generations, wherever you live."
23.15: "Starting the day after the Sabbath, count for yourselves seven weeks from the day you brought the sheaf of the wave offering. They are to be complete.
23.16: Count fifty days to the day after the seventh Sabbath, then bring a new meal offering to the LORD.
23.17: Bring two loaves of bread from home as wave offerings made from two tenths of fine flour baked with leaven as first fruits to the LORD.
23.18: Along with the loaves of bread, bring seven lambs (each of them one year old and without defect), one young bull as an offering, and two rams as offerings to the LORD—along with your gift and drink offerings—and present them as an offering made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
23.19: Prepare one male goat for a sin offering and two one year old rams for peace offerings.
23.20: Then the priest is to wave them—the two lambs with the bread of first fruits—as raised offerings in the LORD's presence. They'll be sacred to the LORD on account of the priest.
23.21: "On the same day, proclaim a sacred assembly for yourselves. You are not to do any servile work—and this is to be an eternal ordinance wherever you live throughout your generations.
23.22: Furthermore, when you harvest the produce of your land, you are not to harvest all the way to the corners of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest. Leave them for the poor and resident alien. I am the LORD your God."
23.24: "Tell the Israelis that on the first day of the seventh month you are to have a Sabbath of rest for you—a memorial announced by a loud blast of trumpets. It is to be a sacred assembly.
23.25: You are not to do any servile work. Instead, bring an offering made by fire to the LORD."
23.27: "However, on the tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement. It's a sacred assembly for you. Humble yourselves and bring an offering made by fire to the LORD.
23.28: You are not to do any work that same day. It's the Day of Atonement, because your atonement is made in the presence of the LORD your God.
23.29: Anyone who doesn't humble himself that same day is to be eliminated from contact with his people.
23.30: I'll eliminate anyone who does work that day from among his people.
23.31: You are not to do any work. This is to be an eternal ordinance throughout your generations, wherever you live.
23.32: It's a Sabbath of rest for you on which you are to humble yourselves starting the evening of the ninth day of the month. You are to observe your Sabbath from evening to evening."
23.34: "Tell the Israelis that starting the fifteenth day of this seventh month is the week-long Festival of Tents to the LORD.
23.35: On the first day, you are to hold a sacred assembly, when you are not to do any servile work.
23.36: For seven days, bring offerings made by fire to the LORD. The eighth day is also to be a sacred assembly for you. Bring offerings made by fire to the LORD. It's a sacred assembly. You are not to do any servile work.
23.37: "These are the LORD's appointed festivals that you are to proclaim as sacred assemblies. Bring offerings made by fire to the LORD—a whole burnt offering, a meal offering, a sacrifice, and drink offerings. Do this every day on its assigned date
23.38: in addition to the LORD's Sabbath—regarding your gifts, your offerings in fulfillment of vows, and your freely given offerings that you will bring to the LORD.
23.39: "On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you've harvested the produce of the land, you are to observe the festival of the LORD for seven days. The first day is to be a Sabbath rest, and the eighth day also is to be a Sabbath rest.
23.40: "On the first day, take branches from impressive fruit trees, branches from palm trees, boughs from thick trees, and poplars from the brooks. Then you are to rejoice in the presence of the LORD your God for seven days.
23.41: Observe it as a pilgrimage festival in the presence of the LORD for seven days of the year. This is to be an eternal ordinance throughout your generations. Observe the festival during the seventh month.
23.42: You are to live in tents for seven days. Every native born of Israel is to live in tents
23.43: in order for your future generations to know that the Israelis lived in tents when I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God."
23.44: This is what Moses spoke about to the Israelis regarding the LORD's appointed festivals.

24.2: "Tell the Israelis that they are to bring to you pure oil made from beaten olives in order to keep the lamp burning continuously.
24.3: Outside the Canopy of the Testimony in the Tent of Meeting, Aaron is to arrange it continually in the LORD's presence from evening until morning as an eternal ordinance throughout your generations.
24.4: He is to arrange the lamps so that they burn continuously on a ceremonially pure lamp stand in the LORD's presence.
24.5: Take fine flour and bake twelve cakes using two tenths of a measure for each cake.
24.6: Arrange them in two rows—six in each row—on a ceremonially pure table in the LORD's presence.
24.7: Put pure frankincense on each row for a memorial offering. It will serve as an offering made by fire to the LORD.
24.8: They are to be arranged every Sabbath day in the LORD's presence as a gift from the Israelis—an eternal covenant.
24.9: This gift will belong to Aaron and his sons, and they are to eat it in a sacred place, because it's the most holy thing for him of all the offerings made by fire to the LORD. This is to be an eternal ordinance."
24.10: Now a son of an Israeli woman and an Egyptian man went out among the Israelis. The Israeli woman's son got into a fight with an Israeli man in the camp.
24.11: Then the Israeli woman's son blasphemed the Name and cursed, so they brought him to Moses. His mother's name was Shelomith, the daughter of Dibri, from the tribe of Dan.
24.12: They placed him in custody until a decision would be made to them according to the word of the LORD.
24.13: Then the LORD spoke to Moses,
24.14: "Take the one who cursed outside the camp. Everyone who heard him is to lay their hands on his head. Then the entire congregation is to stone him to death.
24.15: Moreover, tell the Israelis that anyone who curses his God will bear the consequences of his own sin,
24.16: because the one who blasphemes the name of the LORD is certainly to be put to death. The entire congregation is to stone him to death. As it is for the resident alien, so it is to be with the native born: when he blasphemes the Name, he is to be put to death.
24.17: "If a man beats a human being to death, he is certainly to be executed,
24.18: but whoever beats an animal to death is to replace it—life for life.
24.19: If a man disfigures his fellow, whatever he did is to be done to him also.
24.20: Fracture for fracture, eye for eye, tooth for tooth—just as he had caused a disfigurement against another man, so it is to be done against him.
24.21: Whoever beats an animal to death is to replace it, but whoever beats a human being to death is to be put to death.
24.22: You are to have for yourselves consistent procedures in deciding a case. As it is for the resident alien, so it is for the native born. I am the LORD your God."
24.23: So Moses spoke to the Israelis and they brought the one who cursed outside the camp and stoned him to death with boulders. The Israelis did just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

25.1: The LORD told Moses on Mount Sinai,
25.2: "Tell the Israelis that when you enter the land that I'm about to give you, you are to let the land observe a Sabbath to the LORD.
25.3: For six years you may plant your fields, and for six years you may prune your vineyard and gather its produce.
25.4: But the seventh year is to be a Sabbath of rest for the land—a Sabbath for the LORD. You are not to plant your field or prune your vineyard.
25.5: You are not to gather what grows from the spilled kernels of your crops. You are not to pick the grapes of your untrimmed vines. Let it be a year of Sabbath for the land.
25.6: You may take the Sabbath produce of the land for your food—you, your male and maid servants, your hired laborers, and the resident alien with you.
25.7: The cattle and the wild animals in your land—everything it produces—are for your food.
25.8: "Count for yourselves seven years of Sabbaths—seven times seven years. This set of seven weeks of years total 49 years for you.
25.9: Sound a horn on the tenth day of the seventh month of this fiftieth year. Likewise, on the Day of Atonement, sound the horn throughout your land.
25.10: Set aside and consecrate the fiftieth year to declare liberty throughout the land for all of its inhabitants. It is to be a jubilee for you. Every person is to return to his own land that he has inherited. Likewise, every person is to return to his tribe.
25.11: The fiftieth year is to be a year of jubilee for you. You are not to sow or harvest the spilled kernels that grow of themselves or pick grapes from the untrimmed vines
25.12: because it's the jubilee—it's sacred for you. But you may eat its produce from the field.
25.13: "During this year of jubilee, each person is to return to his own land that he has inherited.
25.14: So if you had sold property to a neighbor or had acquired land from your neighbor, you are not to cheat one another.
25.15: According to the number of years after the jubilee, you may buy from your neighbor. And according to the number of years with crops, he may sell to you.
25.16: If the number of years after the jubilee is more, increase the selling price. If the number of years after the jubilee is few, decrease its selling price, because he's selling to you according to the potential production volume of the land.
25.17: No one is to cheat his neighbor. Instead, you are to fear your God, because I am the LORD your God.
25.18: "Observe my statutes and keep my ordinances. Do them so that you may live securely in the land.
25.19: Then the land will yield its fruit and you'll eat to your satisfaction and live securely.
25.20: "Now if you ask, 'What will we eat during the seventh year? After all, we may not plant or even gather our produce!'
25.21: I'll command my blessing on you during the sixth year so that it will yield produce for three years!
25.22: That way, you are to sow in the eighth year, eating the produce from the old harvest. Until the ninth year when its produce comes in, you'll eat from the old harvest."
25.23: "The land is not to be sold with any finality, because the land belongs to me. You're sojourners and travelers with me.
25.24: So throughout all of your land inheritance, grant the right of redemption for the land.
25.25: "If your brother becomes so poor that he has to a sell portion of his inheritance, then his nearest kinsman redeemer is to come and redeem what his brother has sold.
25.26: If a person doesn't have a kinsman redeemer, but has become rich and found sufficient means for his redemption,
25.27: then let him account for the years for which it was sold, return the excess to the person to whom it was sold, and then return to his property.
25.28: If he's not able to redeem it back for himself, then what he sold is to remain in the hand of the buyer until the year of jubilee. In the jubilee, it is to be returned so he may return to his property.
25.29: "If a person sells a residential house in a walled city, he is to redeem it within the year in which it was sold. He may have right to its redemption for a full year.
25.30: But if it's not redeemed by the end of a full year, then the house next to which is a wall is to belong in perpetuity to the one who bought it throughout his generations. It is not to be returned in the jubilee.
25.31: However, the houses in the villages that don't have walls around them are to be categorized along with the fields of the land—they may be redeemed and returned in the jubilee.
25.32: Nevertheless, the cities that belong to the descendants of Levi—that is, the houses in the cities that belong to them—are to belong to the descendants of Levi perpetually as part of their right of redemption.
25.33: If someone from the descendants of Levi redeems the houses in the cities that they own, they are to be returned in the jubilee, because the houses of the cities of the descendants of Levi are to remain their property among the Israelis.
25.34: Also, the open land of their cities is not to be sold, because it is to remain their perpetual inheritance."
25.35: "If your relative becomes so poor that he is indebted to you, then you are to support him. You are to let him live with you just like the resident alien and the traveler.
25.36: You are not to take interest or profit from him. Instead, you are to fear your God and let your relative live with you.
25.37: You are not to loan him money with interest or sell him your food at a profit.
25.38: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.
25.39: "If your brother with you becomes so poor that he sells himself to you, you are not to make him serve like a bond slave.
25.40: Instead, he is to serve with you like a hired servant or a traveler who lives with you, until the year of jubilee.
25.41: Then he and his children with him may leave to return to his family and his ancestor's inheritance.
25.42: Since they're my servants whom I've brought out of the land of Egypt, they are not to be sold as slaves.
25.43: You are not to rule over them with harshness. You are to fear your God."
25.44: "As for your male and maid slaves who will be with you, you may buy male and female slaves from among the nations.
25.45: You may also buy from resident aliens who live among you and their families who are with you, whom they fathered in your land. They may become your property.
25.46: You may give them as inherited property to your children after you, to own as properties in perpetuity. You may make bond slaves of them, but no one is to rule over his fellow Israeli with harshness.
25.47: "If a resident alien or traveler becomes rich, but your relative who lives next to him is so poor that he sells himself to that resident alien or traveler among you or to a member of the resident alien's family,
25.48: he has the right to be redeemed after he sells himself. One of his brothers may redeem him.
25.49: His uncle or his uncle's son may redeem him or any blood relative from his tribe may redeem him. If he becomes rich, then he may redeem himself.
25.50: "He is to bring an accounting to the one who bought him, starting from the year he had sold himself until the year of jubilee. The price of his sale is to correspond to the number of years comparable to the time a hired servant stays with him.
25.51: If there are still many years left, he is to refund the cost of his redemption.
25.52: But if only a few years are left until the year of jubilee, he is to bring an accounting of the years that he is to refund for his redemption.
25.53: Like a hired servant, he is to remain with him year after year, but he is not to rule over him with what you see as severity.
25.54: If he isn't redeemed by these, then he is to be set free in the year of jubilee—he and his children with him—
25.55: because the Israelis are my servants. They're my servants, since I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God."

26.1: "You are not to make worthless idols, images, or pillars for yourselves, nor set up for yourselves carved images to bow down to them in the land, because I am the LORD your God.
26.2: "You are to keep my Sabbath and fear my sanctuary. I am the LORD.
26.3: "If you live by my statutes, obey my commands, and observe them,
26.4: then I'll send your rain in its season so that the land will yield its produce and the trees of the field will yield their fruit.
26.5: Threshing will extend to the time of vintage and the vintage will extend to the time of sowing, so that you'll eat your bread to your satisfaction and live securely in your land.
26.6: I'll give peace in the land so that you'll lie down without fear. I'll remove wild beasts from the land, and not even war will come to your land.
26.7: Instead, you'll pursue your enemies and they'll die by the sword before you.
26.8: Five of you will chase a hundred, a hundred of you will chase ten thousand, and your enemies will fall by the sword before you.
26.9: "I'll look after you, ensuring that you'll be fruitful. I'll increase your number and keep my covenant with you.
26.10: When you have consumed what was stored of the old, then you'll take out the old and replace it with what's new.
26.11: I'll set up my tent in your midst and I won't loathe you.
26.12: I'll walk among you. I will be your God, and you'll be my people.
26.13: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt so that you will no longer be their slaves, since I've broken their oppressive yoke upon you to make you walk upright."
26.14: "But if you won't listen to me and obey all these commands,
26.15: and if you refuse my statutes, loathe my ordinances, and fail to carry out all of my commands, thereby breaching my covenant,
26.16: then I will certainly do this to you: I'll appoint sudden terror to infect you like tuberculosis and fever. Your eyes will fail and your life will waste away. You'll plant in vain, because your enemies will consume what you plant.
26.17: I'll set my face against you so that you'll be defeated before your enemies. Those who hate you will have dominion over you and you'll keep fleeing even when no one is pursuing you.
26.18: "If, despite all of this, you still don't listen to me, then I'll punish you seven times more on account of your sins.
26.19: I'll break your mighty pride. I'll make the heavens to be like iron and the ground like bronze.
26.20: Your strength will be spent in vain, because your land won't yield its produce and the trees of the land won't yield their fruit.
26.21: "If you live life contrary to me and remain unwilling to listen to me, then I'll add to your wounds seven times more on account of your sins.
26.22: I'll send wild beasts against you from the open country to deprive you of your children, destroy your cattle, and decrease your number so that your roads become desolate.
26.23: "If, despite these things, you still won't return to me, but live life contrary to me,
26.24: then I'll certainly oppose you. I'll take vengeance against you seven fold on account of your sins.
26.25: I'll bring the sword against you to execute the vengeance of my covenant. When you gather in your cities, I'll send a pestilence. As a result, you'll be delivered into the control of your enemies.
26.26: When I destroy the source of your bread, ten women will bake bread in one oven. Then they'll return back your bread by weight. You'll eat but won't be satisfied.
26.27: "If, after all of this time, you don't listen to me, but instead live life contrary to me,
26.28: I'll oppose you with vicious rage. Indeed, I myself will punish you seven fold on account of your sins.
26.29: At that time, you'll eat the flesh of your sons and you'll eat the flesh of your daughters.
26.30: I'll destroy your high places and cut down your sun pillars. Then I'll cast your dead bodies on top of the bodies of your idols. I'll loathe you.
26.31: I'll lay your cities to waste and destroy your sanctuaries so I don't have to smell the scent of your soothing odors.
26.32: I'll make the land so desolate that your enemies who live in it will be astonished."
26.33: "I'll scatter you among the nations and draw the sword after you so that your land becomes desolate and your towns become ruins.
26.34: Then the land will finally be pleased with its Sabbaths as long as it lies desolate while you are in the land of your enemies. At that time, the land will rest and take its Sabbaths.
26.35: As long as it lies desolate, it will have rest that it will not have had during your Sabbaths when you were living in it.
26.36: "As for the remnants among you, I'll bring despair in their hearts in the land of their enemies so that even the sound of a blown leaf will chase them and they flee as though pursued by the sword and fall when no one is pursuing.
26.37: They'll stumble over each other as though fleeing before the sword, even though no one is pursuing. "You won't have power to resist your enemies.
26.38: You'll perish among the nations and the land of your enemies will consume you.
26.39: The remnants among you will waste away in the land of your enemies due to their iniquity. Indeed, they'll also waste away on account of the iniquities of their ancestors with them."
26.40: "Nevertheless, when they confess their iniquity, the iniquity of their ancestors, and their unfaithfulness by which they acted unfaithfully against me by living life contrary to me—
26.41: causing me to oppose them and take them to the land of their enemies so that the uncircumcised foreskin of their hearts can be humbled and so that they accept the punishment of their iniquity—
26.42: then I'll remember my covenant with Jacob, my covenant with Isaac, and my covenant with Abraham. I'll also remember the land.
26.43: They will leave the land so it can rest while it lies desolate without them. That's when they'll receive the punishment of their iniquity, because indeed they will have rejected my ordinances and despised my statutes.
26.44: Yet, despite all of these things, when they're in the land of their enemies, I won't reject or despise them so as to completely destroy them and by doing so violate my covenant with them, because I am the LORD their God.
26.45: Instead, on account of them, I'll remember my covenant with their ancestors when I brought them out of the land of Egypt right before the eyes of the nations, so that I could be their God. I am the LORD."
26.46: These are the statutes, ordinances, and laws that the LORD made between himself and the Israelis on Mount Sinai, as recorded by the hand of Moses.

27.2: "Tell the Israelis that when a person makes a special vow based on the appropriate value of people who belong to the LORD,
27.3: if your valuation of the vow is for a male from 20 to 60 years old, the valuation is to be 50 shekels of silver, according to the shekel of the sanctuary.
27.4: If she is a female from 20 to 60 years old, then your valuation is to be 30 shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary.
27.5: If a person is from five to 20 years, then your valuation for a male is to be 20 shekels and for a female ten shekels.
27.6: If a person is from one month to five years old, then your valuation for a male is to be five shekels of silver, and for a female your valuation is to be three shekels of silver.
27.7: If a person is 60 or more years old, then your valuation for a male is to be fifteen shekels and for a female ten shekels.
27.8: But if he is too poor to be valuated, then cause him to stand before the priest and let the priest set a value on him according to the ability of the one making the vow.
27.9: "If it's an animal from which they make an offering to the LORD, everything that he gives to the LORD from it will be holy.
27.10: He is not to substitute it or exchange it—the good with the bad or the bad with the good. If he ever makes an exchange of an animal for an animal, then it and what's being exchanged is holy.
27.11: If any animal is unclean, which cannot be brought to the LORD as an offering, make the animal stand in the presence of the priest,
27.12: then the priest will evaluate it as to whether it is good or bad. According to your—that is, the priest's—valuation, so it is to be.
27.13: If a kinsman redeemer decides to redeem it, then he is to add a fifth to your valuation."
27.14: "If a person consecrates his house to be holy to the LORD, then the priest is to set a value for it as to its worth, whether good or bad. As the priest sets value on it, so it will stand.
27.15: And if he that consecrated it wishes to redeem his house, he is to add one fifth to your valuation, after which it is to belong to him.
27.16: "If a person consecrates to the LORD a portion of the field from his inheritance, then your valuation is to be based on its capacity for yielding a harvest. Each omer of barley is to be valued at 50 shekels of silver.
27.17: If he consecrates his field in the year of jubilee, it is to be based on your valuation.
27.18: If he consecrates his field after the jubilee, then the priest is to account to him the silver according to the years that remain until the year of jubilee, with a deduction corresponding to your valuation.
27.19: "If the one who consecrated the field intends to redeem it, then he is to add one fifth of your valuation to it in silver, then it is to be established as his.
27.20: But if he won't redeem the field, but instead sells it to another person, then it is not to be redeemed anymore.
27.21: When the field is released in the jubilee, it will be holy to the LORD. As a field that's devoted, it is to belong to the priest as his inheritance.
27.22: If he consecrates a field that he had bought and that isn't part of his inheritance,
27.23: then the priest is to account to him the evaluated worth until the year of jubilee. Then he is to give the amount of valuation on that day as a holy gift to the LORD.
27.24: During the year of jubilee, the field is to be returned by the one who originally sold it—that is, to the owner of the land.
27.25: Every valuation is to be according to the shekel of the sanctuary, evaluated at 20 gerahs to the shekel.
27.26: "No person is to consecrate the firstborn, because the firstborn of the animals already belongs to the LORD. Whether ox or goat, it belongs to the LORD.
27.27: If it's an unclean animal, then he is to ransom it according to your valuation, adding a fifth to it. If it's not redeemed, then it is to be sold according to your valuation.
27.28: However, any devoted thing that a person consecrates to the LORD from what he owns—whether man, animals, or inherited fields—is not to be sold or redeemed. Any devoted thing is most sacred. It belongs to the LORD.
27.29: But anyone who is completely devoted from among human beings is not to be ransomed. He is certainly to be put to death.
27.30: "Any tithes of the land—from grain grown on the land or from fruit grown on the trees—belong to the LORD. They are sacred to the LORD.
27.31: But if a person wishes to redeem his tithe, he is to add a fifth to it.
27.32: All the tithes from cattle and flocks that pass under the measuring rod are sacred to the LORD.
27.33: He is not to examine it to see if it's good or bad or even exchange it. If he does exchange it, what has been exchanged as well as its substitute is sacred. It is not to be redeemed."
27.34: These are the commands that the LORD commanded Moses to deliver to the Israelis on Mount Sinai.

1.1: In the Sinai desert, the LORD spoke to Moses inside the Tent of Meeting on the first day of the second month of the second year after they had left the land of Egypt. He said,
1.2: "Take a census of the entire Israeli community, numbering them by their tribes and by ancestral houses. List the names of every male one-by-one,
1.3: from 20 years and upward. You and Aaron are to register everyone in Israel who is able to go to war, company by company.
1.4: One man from each tribe is to accompany you, each man being the leader of his ancestral house.
1.5: "Here is a list of names of the men who are to assist you: "From Reuben: Shedeur's son Elizur.
1.10: "From Joseph's descendants through Ephraim: Ammihud's son Elishama. From Manasseh: Pedahzur's son Gamaliel.
1.16: These men were appointed from within their communities, since they were leaders of their ancestral houses and heads of the tribes of Israel.
1.17: Moses and Aaron gathered these men who had been mentioned by name.
1.18: They assembled the entire community together during the second month. Then they recorded their ancestries, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as well as the names of the men 20 years old and above individually,
1.19: just as the LORD had commanded Moses. He numbered them in the Sinai desert.
1.20: The genealogies of the descendants of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel, were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.21: Those registered with the tribe of Reuben numbered 46,500.
1.22: The genealogies of Simeon's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.23: Those registered with the tribe of Simeon numbered 59,300.
1.24: The genealogies of Gad's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.25: Those registered with the tribe of Gad numbered 45,650.
1.26: The genealogies of Judah's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.27: Those registered with the tribe of Judah numbered 74,600.
1.28: The genealogies of Issachar's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.29: Those registered with the tribe of Issachar numbered 54,400.
1.30: The genealogies of Zebulun's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.31: Those registered with the tribe of Zebulun numbered 57,400.
1.32: The genealogies of Joseph's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.33: Those registered with the tribe of Joseph numbered 40,500.
1.34: The genealogies of Manasseh's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.35: Those registered with the tribe of Manasseh numbered 32,200.
1.36: The genealogies of Benjamin's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.37: Those registered with the tribe of Benjamin numbered 35,400.
1.38: The genealogies of Dan's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.39: Those registered with the tribe of Dan numbered 62,700.
1.40: The genealogies of Asher's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.41: Those registered with the tribe of Asher numbered 41,500.
1.42: The genealogies of Naphtali's descendants were recorded individually, according to their tribes and ancestral houses, as were the names of all the men 20 years and above who could serve in the army.
1.43: Those registered with the family of Naphtali numbered 53,400.
1.44: These individuals were the ones whom Moses and Aaron registered from the twelve leaders of Israel, each person from his ancestral house.
1.45: Everyone was numbered from the descendants of Israel, from their ancestral houses, from all the men who were 20 years and above and who could serve in the army.
1.46: The total of all those who were numbered was 603,550.
1.47: The descendants of Levi were not counted according to their ancestral houses
1.48: because the LORD had ordered Moses:
1.49: "Be sure not to number or count the tribe of Levi with the rest of the Israelis.
1.50: Instead, appoint the descendants of Levi over the Tent of Meeting, all the vessels, and everything in it. They are to carry the tent and all the vessels in it. They are to attend to it and camp around it.
1.51: Whenever the tent is ready for travel, the descendants of Levi are to take it down. When it's time to encamp, the descendants of Levi are to set it up. Any unauthorized person who approaches it is to be executed.
1.52: Then the Israelis are to encamp around the tent, arranged according to their company and the standard of their army.
1.53: But the descendants of Levi are to encamp on all sides of the Tent of Meeting so that divine wrath won't fall on the congregation of Israel. The descendants of Levi are to take care of the Tent of Meeting."
1.54: The Israelis observed everything that the LORD had commanded Moses, doing exactly what they were told.

2.1: Later, the LORD told Moses and Aaron,
2.2: "Every single Israeli is to encamp beneath his standard with the emblem of his ancestral house. The Israelis are to encamp in front of and surrounding the Tent of Meeting."
2.3: "The encampment of Judah is to settle east toward the sunrise under their standard. The leader of Judah is to be Amminadab's son Nahshon.
2.5: "The tribe of Issachar is to encamp beside Judah. The leader of Issachar is to be Zuar's son Nethanel.
2.7: "Next is to be the tribe of Zebulun. The leader of Zebulun is to be Helon's son Eliab.
2.9: All those numbered by division in the camp of Judah total 186,400. They are to be the first to travel."
2.10: "Toward the south is to be the division of the camp of Reuben under their standard. The leader of Reuben is to be Shedeur's son Elizur.
2.12: "The tribe of Simeon is to camp beside Reuben. The leader of Simeon is to be Zurishaddai's son Shelumiel.
2.14: "Next is to be the tribe of Gad. The leader of Gad is to be Deuel's son Eliasaph.
2.16: All those numbered by division in the camp of Reuben total 151,450. They are to be the second to travel."
2.17: "Then the Tent of Meeting is to travel with the camp of the descendants of Levi in the middle of the camps. They are to travel just as they have camped, each as designated under his standard."
