21.10: After this, the Israelis traveled and encamped at Oboth.
21.11: Then they traveled from Oboth and encamped at Iye-abarim, in the wilderness that is in the vicinity of Moab's eastern border.
21.12: From there, they traveled and encamped in the valley of Zered.
21.13: Then they traveled to the other side of Arnon and camped in the wilderness that borders the territory of the Amorites. (Arnon borders Moab between Moab and the Amorites,
21.14: which is why the Book of the Wars of the LORD reads, "Waheb and Suphah and the wadis of the Arnon,
21.15: and the slope of the valleys, that extends to the dwelling places of Ar and the borders of Moab.")
21.16: From there they traveled to the Well of Beer, where the LORD had instructed Moses, "Gather the people together and I'll give you water."
21.17: That's also where Israel sang this song: Rise up, well! Sing to it!
21.18: It's the well that the leaders dug, the one carved out by the nobles of the people with their scepters and staffs. Then they moved on in the wilderness from there to Mattanah,
21.19: then from Mattanah to Nahaliel, from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
21.20: and from Bamoth to the valley of Moab where their fields are, and from there to the top of Mount Pisgah, that looks down toward the open desert.
21.21: Later, Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who conveyed this request:
21.22: "Permit us to pass through your land. We won't trespass in your fields or vineyards. We won't drink water from any well, and we'll only travel along the King's Highway until we've passed through your territory."
21.23: Instead of letting Israel pass through his territory, Sihon mustered his entire army and marched out to meet them in the wilderness. He arrived at Jahaz and attacked Israel.
21.24: But Israel defeated him in battle and took possession of all his lands from Arnon to Jabbok, including the Ammonites, even though the border of the Ammonites was strong.
21.25: So Israel captured all of those cities, occupied all the Amorite cities in Heshbon, and all its towns.
21.26: Heshbon was the capital city of Sihon, king of the Amorites, who fought against the previous king of Moab and captured all his land from his capital city to Arnon.
21.27: Therefore the ones who speak in proverbs say: Come to Heshbon and let it be built! Let the city of Sihon be established!
21.28: A fire has gone out from Heshbon, and a flame from the city of Sihon. It consumed Ar of Moab and the lords of the high places who lived in Arnon.
21.29: Woe to you, Moab! You are destroyed, you people of Chemosh! He has given up his sons as fugitives and his daughters have gone into captivity to Sihon, king of the Amorites.
21.30: We've fired at them. Heshbon has perished as far as Dibon. We've destroyed them as far as Nophah even as far as Medeba.
21.31: So Israel lived in Amorite territory.
21.32: Then Moses sent out explorers to scout Jazer. They captured its towns and drove out the Amorites who were there.
21.33: Then they turned toward Bashan. However, Og, the king of Bashan, mustered his army and went out to attack them at Edrei.
21.34: The LORD told Moses, "You are not to fear him, because I'm going to deliver him, his entire army, and his land into your control. Do to him just what you've done to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who used to live in Heshbon."
21.35: So they attacked him, his sons, and his entire army, until there wasn't even a single survivor left. Then they took possession of his land.

22.1: The Israelis continued their travels, eventually encamping on the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River opposite Jericho.
22.2: Zippor's son Balak saw everything that Israel had done to the Amorites.
22.3: As a result, Moab greatly feared the people, because they were so numerous. Because a sense of impending doom was afflicting the Moabites as they faced the Israelis,
22.4: the Moabites told the elders of Midian, "This horde of people is about to lick up everything around us, like an ox licks up the green ground." At that time, Zippor's son Balak was the king of Moab.
22.5: He sent messengers to Beor's son Balaam in Pethor, near the Euphrates River, the land where the descendants of his people originated, to summon his aid. He said, "Look! A group of people have escaped from Egypt. They cover the surface of the whole earth, and are sitting here right in front of me.
22.6: So come right now and curse this people for me, because there are too many of them for me to handle. Perhaps I'll be able to strike them down and drive them out of the land, since I know that whomever you bless is blessed and whomever you curse is cursed."
22.7: So the elders of Moab and Midian left to visit Balaam, bringing an honorarium with them, and communicated Balak's concerns to him.
22.8: In answer, Balaam told them, "Stay here for the night and I'll bring back a message to you, depending on what the LORD says to me." So the officers of Moab stayed with Balaam overnight.
22.9: God visited Balaam and asked him, "Who are these men with you?"
22.10: Then Balaam told God, "Zippor's son Balak, king of Moab, sent them to me and said,
22.11: Look! A group of people have escaped from Egypt. They cover the surface of the whole earth! So come right now and curse them for me. Perhaps I'll be able to fight against them and drive them out.'"
22.12: But God told Balaam, "Don't go with them. Don't curse the people, because they're blessed."
22.13: So Balaam got up the next morning and told Balak's officials, "Go back to your homeland, because the LORD has refused me permission to go with you."
22.14: So Balak's officials got up, returned to Balak and reported, "Balaam refused to come with us."
22.15: In response, Balak sent more officers—higher ranking ones, at that!—
22.16: who approached Balaam with this message: "This is what Zippor's son Balak says: 'Don't let anything get in the way of your coming to me.
22.17: I'm determined to reward you generously, and I'll do everything you tell me to do. So come right away and curse this people for me.'"
22.18: Balaam responded to Balak's entourage by saying, "Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I won't double-cross the command of the LORD my God in even the slightest way.
22.19: Meanwhile, stay here overnight so I may learn what the LORD might say to me."
22.20: God came to visit Balaam that same night and told him, "If the men come to call on you, get up and go with them, but be sure to do only what I tell you to do."
22.21: The next morning, Balaam got up, saddled his donkey, and started to leave, accompanied by the Moabite officials.
22.22: At this, the anger of the LORD flared up against Balaam, because he was leaving. So the angel of the LORD stood in the way to oppose him. As Balaam was riding his donkey, accompanied by two of his servants,
22.23: all of a sudden the donkey saw the angel of the LORD standing in the way, with an unsheathed sword in his hand! The donkey turned off the road and went into an open field. Balaam started beating the donkey in order to turn her back to the road,
22.24: but the angel of the LORD stood on a narrow path that crossed the vineyards. It had walls on both sides of the path.
22.25: When the donkey saw the angel of the LORD, she squeezed herself so close to the wall that Balaam's foot was pressed to the wall. So he beat her again!
22.26: Then the angel of the LORD went along a little further and stood in a much narrower space, where it was impossible to turn either right or left.
22.27: When the donkey saw the angel of the LORD, she crouched down under Balaam. As a result, Balaam got so angry that he started to whip the donkey with his staff.
22.28: That's when the LORD enabled the donkey to speak. She asked Balaam, "What did I do to you that you would beat me in the space of only three footsteps?"
22.29: "Because you're playing a dirty trick on me," Balaam answered the donkey. "If only I had a sword in my hand! I'd kill you right now!"
22.30: But in response, the donkey asked Balaam, "I'm your donkey that you've ridden on in the past without incident, am I not, and I'm the same donkey you're riding on right now, am I not? Am I in the habit of treating you like this?" "No," he admitted.
22.31: Then the LORD enabled Balaam to see, so he observed the angel of the LORD standing in the way, with an unsheathed sword in his hand. So he bowed down and prostrated himself on his face.
22.32: Then the angel of the LORD asked him, "Why did you beat your donkey in the space of only three footsteps? I've come to oppose you, because I say that what you're doing is perverted.
22.33: The donkey saw me and turned in front of me in the space of those three footsteps.
22.34: If she hadn't turned away from me, I would have killed you by now and left her alive!" At this, Balaam replied to the angel of the LORD, "I've sinned! I didn't know that you were standing to meet me on the road. So now, since it displeases you, let me go back."
22.35: But the angel of the LORD told Balaam, "Go with the men, but deliver only the message that I'm going to give you." So Balaam went with Balak's officials.
22.36: When Balak heard that Balaam had arrived, he went out to meet him in the city of Moab on the border of Arnon at the extreme end of his territory.
22.37: Balak asked Balaam, "Didn't I repeatedly send for you to summon you? Why didn't you come to me? I can pay you well, can't I?"
22.38: Balaam answered Balak, "Well, I'm here now. I've come to you, but I can't just say anything, can I? I'll speak only what God puts in my mouth to say."
22.39: So accompanied by Balaam and Balak's officials, Balak traveled to Kiriath-huzoth,
22.40: where he sacrificed oxen and sheep.
22.41: The next day, Balak brought Balaam up to Bamoth-baal, where he could see part of the community of Israel.

23.1: Balaam told Balak, "Build for me here seven altars and prepare here for me seven bulls and seven rams."
23.2: So Balak did just as Balaam instructed. Balak and Balaam offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.3: Then Balaam instructed Balak, "Stand by your offering and leave me alone by myself. Perhaps the LORD will come to meet me. I'll tell you whatever he reveals to me." And so he went to a high place,
23.4: where the LORD met with Balaam, who told him, "I've prepared seven altars and offered bulls and rams on an altar."
23.5: Then the LORD gave Balaam this message. "Return to Balak and speak to him."
23.6: So Balaam returned to where Balak had been standing, that is, next to his offerings, accompanied by all the Moabite officials.
23.7: Then Balaam uttered this prophetic statement: "King Balak of Moab brought me from Aram, from the eastern mountains, and told me, 'Come and curse Jacob for me. Come and curse Israel.'
23.8: But how can I curse those whom God hasn't cursed? How can I denounce those whom the LORD hasn't denounced?
23.9: I saw them from the top of the rocks. I watched them from the hills. Truly this is a people that lives by itself and doesn't matter among the nations.
23.10: Who can count the dust of Jacob? Who can number the dust of Israel? Let me die the death of the righteous, and may I end up like him."
23.11: "What are you doing to me?" Balak asked Balaam. "I brought you to curse my enemies, not pronounce a blessing!"
23.12: But in response, Balaam asked, "Shouldn't I be careful to communicate only what the LORD puts in my mouth?"
23.13: "Come with me to another place where you can see them," Balak replied. "You'll only see a portion of them, because you won't be able to see them completely. Come and curse them from there for me."
23.14: So Balak took him to the field of Zophim, and from there to the top of Mount Pisgah, where he built seven altars and then offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
23.15: Then he told Balak, "Stand by your offering while I go alone to meet the LORD."
23.16: Then the LORD met with Balaam and gave a message to him. "Now go back to Balak and speak to him."
23.17: So Balaam returned to where Balak had been standing, that is, next to his offerings, accompanied by the Moabite officials. "What did the LORD say?" Balak asked him.
23.18: In response, Balaam uttered this prophetic statement: "Stand up, Balak, and pay attention! Listen to me, you son of Zippor!
23.19: God is not a human male— he doesn't lie, nor is he a human being— he never vacillates. Once he speaks up, he's going to act, isn't he? Once he makes a promise, he'll fulfill it, won't he?
23.20: Look! I've received a blessing, and so I will bless. I won't withdraw it.
23.21: He has not responded to iniquity in Jacob or gazed at mischief in Israel. The LORD his God is with them, and the triumphant cry of a king is among them.
23.22: From Egypt God brought them— his strength was like a wild ox!
23.23: No Satanic plan against Jacob nor divination against Israel can ever prevail. When the time is right, it is to be asked about Jacob and Israel, 'What has God accomplished?'
23.24: Look! The people are like lions. Like the lion, he rises up! He does not lie down again until he has consumed his prey and drunk the blood of the slain."
23.25: Then Balak told Balaam, "Don't curse them or bless them!"
23.26: "Didn't I tell you," Balaam responded to Balak, "that I'll say whatever the LORD tells me to say?"
23.27: So Balak exhorted Balaam, "Let's go right now! I'll take you to another place. Maybe God will agree to have you curse them for me from there."
23.28: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor, which overlooks the open wilderness.
23.29: Balaam told Balak, "Build seven altars for me right here. Then prepare seven bulls and seven rams."
23.30: Balak did just what Balaam had instructed—he offered a bull and a ram on each altar.

24.1: When Balaam noticed that the LORD was pleased that Balaam was blessing Israel, he didn't behave as he had time after time before, that is, to practice divination. Instead, he turned with his face to the wilderness,
24.2: looked up, and saw Israel encamped in their respective tribal order. Just then, the spirit of God came upon him.
24.3: Balaam uttered this prophetic statement: "A declaration by Beor's son Balaam, a declaration by the strong, blind man.
24.4: A declaration from one who hears what God has to say, who saw the vision that the Almighty revealed, who keeps stumbling with open eyes.
24.5: Jacob, your tents are so fine, as well as your dwelling places, O Israel!
24.6: They're spread out like valleys, like gardens along river banks, like aloe planted by the LORD, or like cedars beside water.
24.7: He will pour water from his buckets, and his descendants will stream forth like abundant water. His king will be more exalted than Agag when he exalts his own kingdom.
24.8: God is bringing them out of Egypt with the strength of an ox. He'll devour enemy nations, break their bones, and impale them with arrows.
24.9: He crouches, laying low like a lion. Who would awaken him? Those who bless you are blessed, and those who curse you are cursed."
24.10: Balak flew into a rage and he started hitting his fists together. "I called you to curse my enemies," he yelled at Balaam. "But look here! You've blessed them three times!
24.11: Now get out of here! I had promised you that I would definitely honor you, but now the LORD has kept me from doing that!"
24.12: But Balaam replied to Balak, "I told your messengers,
24.13: Even if Balak gives me his palace full of silver and gold, I won't double-cross the command of the LORD and do anything—whether good or evil—on my own initiative, because I'm going to say whatever the LORD says.'
24.14: Meanwhile, since I have to return to my people, come and listen while I tell you what this people will be doing to your people in the last days."
24.15: Then Balaam uttered this prophetic statement: "The declaration by Beor's son Balaam, a declaration by the strong, blind man.
24.16: A declaration from one who hears what God has to say, who knows what the Most High knows, who saw the vision that the Almighty revealed, who keeps stumbling with open eyes.
24.17: I can see him, but not right now. I observe him, but from a distance. A star streams forth from Jacob; a scepter arises from Israel. He will crush Moab's forehead, along with all of Seth's descendants.
24.18: Edom will be a conquered nation and Seir will be Israel's defeated foe, while Israel performs valiantly.
24.19: He will rule over Jacob, annihilating those who survive in the city."
24.20: Next, Balaam looked directly at Amalek and then uttered this prophetic statement: "Even though Amalek is an international leader, his future is permanent destruction."
24.21: Balaam also uttered this prophetic statement about the Kenites: "Your dwelling places are stable, because your nest is carved in solid rock.
24.22: Nevertheless, Kain will be incinerated. How long will it take until Asshur takes you hostage?"
24.23: Finally, he uttered this prophetic statement: "Ah, who can live, unless God makes it happen?
24.24: Ships under control of Kittim will devastate Asshur and Eber, until they are permanently destroyed."
24.25: Then Balaam got up, returned to his country, and Balak went on his way.

25.1: While Israel remained encamped in Shittim, the people began to commit sexual immorality with Moabite women,
25.2: who also invited the people to the sacrifices of their gods. So the people ate what they had sacrificed and then worshipped their gods.
25.3: The people joined the Baal-peor cult. As a result, the anger of the LORD flared up against Israel,
25.4: so the LORD told Moses, "Take all the leaders of the people and execute them in broad daylight for the LORD, so the LORD's burning anger may be withdrawn from Israel."
25.5: Then Moses ordered the judges of Israel, "Each one of you is to execute the men in his own tribe who joined the Baal-peor cult."
25.6: That very moment, one of the Israelis arrived, bringing to his brothers one of the Midianite women, right in front of Moses and the entire community of Israel, while they were weeping at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting!
25.7: When Eleazar's son Phinehas, grandson of Aaron the priest saw this, he jumped up from the middle of the community, grabbed a javelin in his hand,
25.8: followed the Israeli man inside his tent, and impaled the two of them—the Israeli man and the woman—right through both of them and into her abdomen. Then the plague infecting the Israelis was brought to a halt. Nevertheless,
25.9: 24,000 people died because of the plague.
25.11: "Eleazar's son Phinehas, grandson of Aaron the priest, has turned my wrath away from Israel. Because his zealousness reflected my own zeal for them, I didn't consume Israel in my jealousy.
25.12: Therefore, I'm certainly going to be giving him my covenant of peace,
25.13: for him and for his descendants after him, too, a covenant of perpetual priesthood, because he was zealous for his God and made atonement for the Israelis."
25.14: Now the name of the Israeli man who was slain, along with the Midianite woman, was Salu's son Zimri, a leader from the tribe of Simeon.
25.15: The woman who was slain, that is, the Midianite woman, was named Cozbi. She was the daughter of Zur, a leader of one of the ancestral houses of Midian.
25.18: because they've acted deceitfully, bringing trouble to you in this incident at Peor with Cozbi, daughter of a prince from Midian, who was killed during the plague that came about because of the incident at Peor."

26.1: After the plague was over, the LORD told Moses and Aaron the priest's son Eleazar,
26.2: "Take a census of the entire community of Israel from the age of 20 years and above, according to each ancestral tribe, counting everyone who is able to go out to war in Israel."
26.3: Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke to them in the plains of Moab, by the Jordan River in Jericho.
26.4: They counted every male Israeli who had come out of Egypt and who was 20 years old and above, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
26.5: From Reuben, Israel's firstborn, the descendants of Reuben included from Hanoch, the family of the descendants of Hanoch; from Pallu, the family of the descendants of Pallu;
26.6: from Hezron, the family of the descendants of Hezron; and from Carmi, the family of the descendants of Carmi.
26.7: These families of the descendants of Reuben numbered 43,730.
26.9: The descendants of Eliab were Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram were removed from the community because they joined the rebellion against Moses and Aaron, as did Korah's company when they rebelled against the LORD.
26.10: The ground had opened its mouth and swallowed them up, along with Korah. Also, that group died when the fire devoured 250 men as a warning sign,
26.11: but Korah's direct descendants didn't die.
26.12: The descendants of Simeon, listed according to their families, included: From Nemuel, the family of the descendants of Nemuel; from Jamin, the family of the descendants of Jamin; from Jachin, the family of the descendants of Jachin;
26.13: from Zerah, the family of the descendants of Zerah; and from Shaul, the family of the descendants of Shaul.
26.14: These families of the descendants of Simeon numbered 22,200.
26.15: The descendants of Gad, listed according to their families, included: From Zephon, the family of the descendants of Zephon; from Haggi, the family of the descendants of Haggi; from Shuni, the family of the descendants of Shuni;
26.16: from Ozni, the family of the descendants of Ozni; from Eri, the family of the descendants of Eri;
26.17: from Arod, the family of the descendants of Arod; and from Areli, the family of the descendants of Areli.
26.18: These families of the descendants of Gad numbered 40,500.
26.19: The descendants of Judah originally included Er and Onan, though Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
26.20: The descendants of Judah, listed according to their families, included: From Shelah, the family of the descendants of Shelah; from Perez, the family of the descendants of Perez; and from Zerah, the family of the descendants of Zerah.
26.21: The descendants of Perez included: From Hezron, the family of the descendants of Hezron; and from Hamul, the family of the descendants of Hamul.
26.23: The tribe of Issachar, listed according to their families, included: From Tola, the family of the descendants of Tola; from Puvah, the family of the descendants of Puvah;
26.24: from Jashub, the family of the descendants of Jashub; and from Shimron, the family of the descendants of Shimron.
26.26: The tribe of Zebulun, listed according to their families, included: From Sered, the family of the descendants of Sered; from Elon, the family of the descendants of Elon; and from Jahleel, the family of the descendants of Jahleel.
26.27: These families of the descendants of Zebulun numbered 60,500.
26.28: The tribe of Joseph, listed according to their families, included Manasseh and Ephraim.
26.29: The descendants of Manasseh included: From Machir, the family of the descendants of Machir. (Machir was the father of Gilead.) From Gilead, the family of the Gileadites
26.30: included: From Iezer, the family of the descendants of Iezer; from Helek, the family of the descendants of Helek;
26.31: from Asriel, the family of the descendants of Asriel; from Shechem, the family of the descendants of Shechem;
26.32: from Shemida, the family of the descendants of Shemida; and from Hepher, the family of the descendants of Hepher.
26.33: Hepher's son Zelophehad had no sons, but the names of Zelophehad's daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
26.35: The descendants of Ephraim, listed according to their families, included: From Shuthelah, the family of the descendants of Shuthelah; from Becher, the family of the descendants of Becher; and from Tahan, the family of the descendants of Tahan.
26.36: The descendants of Shuthelah included from Eran, the family of the descendants of Eran.
26.37: These families of Ephraim numbered 32,500. These were the descendants of Joseph, listed according to their families.
26.38: The tribe of Benjamin, listed according to their families, included: From Bela, the family of the descendants of Bela; from Ashbel, the family of the descendants of Ashbel; from Ahiram, the family of the descendants of Ahiram;
26.39: from Shephupham, the family of the descendants of Shephupham; and from Hupham, the family of the descendants of Hupham.
26.40: The descendants of Bela were Ard and Naaman: From Ard, the family of the descendants of Ard; and from Naaman, the family of the descendants of Naaman.
26.41: These descendants of Benjamin's families numbered 45,600.
26.42: The tribe of Dan, listed according to their families, included the families of the descendants of Shuham.
26.43: All the families of the Shuhamites numbered 64,400.
26.44: The tribe of Asher, listed according to their families, included: From Imnah, the family of the descendants of Imnah; from Ishvi, the family of the descendants of Ishvi; and from Beriah, the family of the descendants of Beriah.
26.45: The descendants of Beriah included: From Heber, the family of the descendants of Heber; and from Malchiel, the family of the descendants of Malchiel.
26.46: (The name of Asher's daughter was Serah.)
26.48: The tribe of Naphtali, listed according to their families, included: From Jahzeel, the family of the descendants of Jahzeel; from Guni, the family of the descendants of Guni;
26.49: from Jezer, the family of the descendants of Jezer; and from Shillem, the family of the descendants of Shillem.
26.51: The total of those numbered among the Israelis was 601,730.
26.53: "The land is to be divided for an inheritance according to the total number of these names.
26.54: The more there are in number, you are to increase their inheritance, and the less there are in number, you are to decrease their inheritance. You are to provide an inheritance to each based on the size of their family,
26.55: but the land is to be divided by lot, inheriting according to the names of their ancestor's tribe.
26.56: Depending on the lot, the portion of their inheritance is to be divided between those with more members and those with fewer members."
26.57: Those who were numbered from the descendants of Levi, listed according to their families, included: From Gershon, the family of the descendants of Gershon; from Kohath, the family of the descendants of Kohath; and from Merari, the family of the descendants of Merari.
26.58: These were the families of Levi: The family of the descendants of Libni, the family of the descendants of Hebron, the family of the descendants of Mahli, the family of the descendants of Musha, and the family of the descendants of Korah. Now Kohath had a son named Amram.
26.59: Amram's wife was Levi's daughter Jochebed, who was born to Levi in Egypt. She gave birth to Aaron, Moses, and their sister Miriam.
26.60: To Aaron were born Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
26.61: But Nadab and Abihu died when they offered unauthorized fire in the LORD's presence.
26.62: All of those individuals numbered 23,000. No male from the age of a month and above was numbered among the Israelis because no inheritance was to be assigned to them among the Israelis.
26.63: So this has been a list of those who were registered by Moses and Eleazar the priest when they numbered the Israelis in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho.
26.64: But none of these men among these numbered by Moses and by Aaron the priest (that is, when they numbered the Israelis in the wilderness of Sinai) survived to enter the land,
26.65: because the LORD had said about them, "They'll certainly die in the wilderness. No man will survive from them except Jephunneh's son Caleb and Nun's son Joshua."

27.1: Now the daughters of Hepher's son Zelophehad, Gilead's grandson, who had been fathered by Machir, who had been fathered by Manasseh, from the tribe of Manasseh, the direct son of Joseph, were named Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They approached
27.2: Moses, Eleazar the priest, the elders, and the entire community at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, stood before them, and said,
27.3: "Our father died in the wilderness, but he wasn't with the company of those who gathered against the LORD along with the company of Korah. He died in his own sin, and he had no sons.
27.4: Why are you going to eliminate the name of our father from his family, just because he had no son? Give us a possession from among our father's relatives."
27.5: So Moses brought the family into the LORD's presence,
27.7: "The daughters of Zelophehad are telling the truth. You are certainly to give to them a possession for an inheritance among their father's relatives. You are to pass on the inheritance of their father to them.
27.8: Tell the Israelis that when a man dies without a son, you are to pass his inheritance to his daughter.
27.9: If he doesn't have a daughter, give his inheritance to his brothers.
27.10: If he doesn't have brothers, give his inheritance to his father's brothers.
27.11: If his father doesn't have brothers, then give his inheritance to a relative who is nearest to him from the family and he'll take possession of it. This is to be a permanent ordinance for the Israelis, just as the LORD commanded Moses."
27.12: Then the LORD told Moses, "You are to climb these Abarim mountains and look over the land that I'm going to give the Israelis.
27.13: After you've seen it, you'll be taken to be with your people just as your brother Aaron was gathered to them,
27.14: because in the wilderness of Zin, when the community rebelled, you rebelled against my command to treat me as holy before their eyes in regards to the Meribah Springs in Kadesh in the wilderness of Zin."
27.16: "May the LORD God of the spirits of all living creatures appoint a man over the community
27.17: who will go in and out before them, and who will lead them out and bring them in so that the LORD'S community won't be like a flock without a shepherd."
27.18: "Select Nun's son Joshua. The Spirit is in that man," the LORD answered Moses. "You are to lay your hand on him
27.19: and make him stand in front of Eleazar the priest and the entire community. Then you are to set him in charge right before their eyes,
27.20: turning over your authority to him so that the entire community of Israel knows to obey him.
27.21: You are to make him stand in the presence of Eleazar the priest, who is to inquire on his behalf using the Urim in the presence of the LORD regarding a decision of judgment, because by his command he and all the Israelis with him will go out or come in."
27.22: So Moses did what the LORD had commanded him. He took Joshua, made him stand in the presence of Eleazar the priest and the entire community,
27.23: laid his hands on him, and charged him, just as the LORD had commanded, using Moses' authority.

28.2: "You are to command the Israelis about my offerings that they are to be sure to bring edible offerings to me, presented by fire, and a pleasing aroma to me, at their appointed time.
28.3: Tell them that this is the offering, presented by fire, that you are to offer to the LORD: two one year old lambs, offered daily every day.
28.4: Offer the first lamb in the morning and the second toward the evening,
28.5: accompanied by one tenth of an ephah of fine flour for grain offering, mixed with one fourth of a hin of pure olive oil.
28.6: This burnt offering, which was prescribed at Mount Sinai, is to be offered every day as a pleasing aroma made by fire to the LORD.
28.7: "The drink offering is to be one fourth of a hin for each lamb. You are to pour out a drink offering of strong wine to the LORD in the Holy Place.
28.8: You are also to offer the second lamb toward the evening. Just like the morning sacrifice, you are to present the grain offering, accompanied by its corresponding drink offering, as a presentation made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD."
28.9: "Every Sabbath day, you are to offer two one year old lambs without any defects with two tenths of an ephah of fine flour for grain offering, mixed with olive oil, along with their corresponding drink offering.
28.10: This burnt offering is to be presented every Sabbath, as well as the regular burnt offering, along with its corresponding drink offering."
28.11: "On the first day of each month, you are to offer a burnt offering to the LORD consisting of two young bulls, one ram, and seven one year old lambs, all of them without any defects,
28.12: along with three tenths of an ephah of fine flour for a grain offering, mixed with olive oil, for each bull, two tenths of an ephah of fine flour for a grain offering, mixed with olive oil, for the one ram,
28.13: and one tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering for each lamb. This burnt offering will be a pleasing aroma, incinerated as an offering to the LORD.
28.14: Their drink offerings are to be half a hin of wine for each bull, one third of a hin for the ram, and one fourth of a hin for each lamb. This burnt offering is to be presented each and every month throughout the year.
28.15: One goat is to be offered at regular intervals as a sin offering to the LORD, accompanied by its corresponding drink offering."
28.16: "The LORD's Passover is to take place on the fourteenth day of the first month.
28.17: You are to hold a festival on the fifteenth day of this month for seven days, during which time unleavened bread is to be eaten."
28.18: "On the first day, you are to hold a sacred assembly. No servile work is to be done.
28.19: Bring an offering that is to be incinerated in the LORD's presence, consisting of two young bulls, a ram, and seven one year old lambs, all without any defects,
28.20: along with their grain offering of fine flour mixed with olive oil. Offer three tenths of an ephah for each bull, two tenths of an ephah for the ram,
28.21: and one tenth of an ephah for each of the seven lambs.
28.22: Then present one goat for a sin offering to make atonement for you,
28.23: apart from the burnt offering in the morning, which you are to continue offering.
28.24: Do this every day for seven days, as an edible sacrifice to the LORD made by fire, a pleasing aroma. It is to be offered apart from the regular burnt offering and its corresponding drink offering.
28.25: On the seventh day you are to hold another sacred assembly for your benefit, on which no servile work is to be done."
28.26: "On the first day of your harvest season, you are to hold a sacred assembly when you present your first fruits during the Festival of Weeks. No servile work is to be done.
28.27: You are to offer this burnt offering as a pleasing aroma to the LORD: two young bulls, one ram, and seven one year old lambs,
28.28: along with their corresponding grain offerings of fine flour mixed with olive oil; specifically, three tenths of an ephah for each bull, two tenths of an ephah for the one ram,
28.29: one tenth of an ephah for each of the seven lambs,
28.30: and one goat to make atonement for you.
28.31: Offer them in addition to the regular burnt offering, accompanied by its grain offering and its corresponding drink offerings."

29.1: "You are to hold a sacred assembly on the first day of the seventh month of each year. No servile work is to be done. It's a day of blowing trumpets for you.

29.3: along with their corresponding grain offering of fine flour mixed with olive oil—three tenths of an ephah for the young bull, two tenths of an ephah for the ram,
29.4: and one tenth of an ephah for each lamb of the seven lambs,
29.5: accompanied by one goat for a sin offering to make atonement for you.

29.33: along with corresponding grain and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs, according to their number, based on the ordinances,
29.34: and accompanied by one goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering, with corresponding grain and drink offerings."

29.37: along with corresponding grain and drink offerings for the bull, ram, and lambs, according to their number, based on the ordinances,

29.40: Moses instructed the Israelis regarding everything that the LORD had commanded him.

30.1: Later, Moses told the elders of the Israeli tribes, "This is what the LORD has commanded:
30.2: When a man makes a vow to the LORD, or swears an oath—an obligation that is binding to himself—he is not to break his word. Instead, he is to fulfill whatever promise came out of his mouth.'"
30.3: "When a young woman makes a vow to the LORD or pledges herself to an obligation while she still lives in her father's house,
30.4: and her father hears her vow and the obligations that she had pledged herself to fulfill, yet her father keeps silent about it, then all her vows and every obligation she pledged herself to are to stand.
30.5: But if her father disallows her on the same day that he hears what she has said, then all her vows and every obligation she had pledged herself to fulfill are not to stand. The LORD will forgive her, because her father has forbidden her."
30.6: "If she has a husband and she makes a vow that is binding on herself, or if she makes a hasty vow with her mouth that she pledges herself to fulfill,
30.7: and her husband hears her vow, yet remains silent on the day that he hears it, then her vows are to stand and the obligation to which she had pledged herself is to stand.
30.8: But if, on the same day her husband hears and disallows her, then he has revoked her vows that she made for herself, along with any hasty vows that she spoke and to which she pledged herself to fulfill. The LORD will forgive her."
30.9: "Everything that a widow or a divorced woman pledges herself to fulfill are to be binding on her.
30.10: If, while she had been living in her late or former husband's house, she makes a vow or a promise that binds her with an oath,
30.11: and her husband hears it but remains silent, not disallowing it, then all her vows are to stand, along with every obligation that she has pledged to fulfill.
30.12: But if her husband disallowed them the very day that he heard her, everything that she spoke relating to her vows and her obligation to herself are not to stand, because her husband revoked them. The LORD will forgive her.
30.13: Her husband may confirm or revoke every vow and binding obligation that afflicts her.
30.14: But if her husband remains silent about her from day to day, then he has affirmed all her vows or obligations that she has obligated herself to fulfill. He has affirmed them because he remained silent from the day he heard her vows.
30.15: But if he nullified them after he had heard, then he will be responsible for any resulting iniquity."
30.16: These are the statutes that the LORD commanded Moses concerning a man and his wife and concerning a father and his young daughter while she still lives in her father's house.

31.2: "Be sure to exact vengeance on behalf of the Israelis from the Midianites, after which you'll be taken home to your people."
31.3: So Moses instructed the people, "Muster your men of war to attack the Midianites and deliver the LORD'S vengeance against Midian.
31.4: Send 1,000 men to war from every tribe throughout all of Israel."
31.5: So 1,000 men from every tribe—12,000 from the thousands of Israel—were mustered and equipped for war.
31.6: Moses sent 1,000 men from every tribe to fight against them, along with Eleazar's son Phinehas, in whose hands were the articles of the sanctuary and trumpets to sound battle alarms.
31.7: They fought against the Midianites just as the LORD had commanded Moses, killing every man.
31.8: They executed the five kings of Midian, including Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba. They also executed Beor's son Balaam with a sword.
31.9: After this, the Israelis took captive the Midianite women and children and confiscated as spoils of war all their cattle, livestock, and their goods.
31.10: They burned every town where they had lived and incinerated all of their encampments.
31.11: They took all the booty and plunder, including both humans and animals.
31.12: Then they brought the captives, booty, and plunder to Moses, to Eleazar the priest, and to the entire community of Israel at the camp on the plains of Moab, by the Jordan River in Jericho.
31.13: Moses and Eleazar the priest and all the leaders of the community went out to meet them outside the camp.
31.14: But Moses became livid with anger at the officers of the army, the captains of thousands, and the captains of hundreds who had returned from servicing in the battle.
31.15: "Did you keep all the women alive?" Moses asked them.
31.16: "Look! These women were the same ones who were counseled by Balaam to cause the Israelis to commit a grievous sin against the LORD at Peor. As a result, that plague infected the LORD's community.
31.17: You are to kill every male child and every woman who has had sexual relations with a man.
31.18: You are to allow the young women who haven't yet had sexual relations with a man to live for yourselves."
31.19: "Now you are to stay outside the camp for seven days, after which any of you who has killed a person or touched someone who was killed may purify yourselves on the third day. You and your captives will be pure on the seventh day.
31.20: Furthermore, you are to purify every garment—that is, everything made of leather, goat's hair, or containing wood."
31.21: Eleazar the priest told the soldiers who had gone to battle, "This is the ordinance of the law that the LORD commanded Moses
31.22: concerning anything containing gold, silver, brass, iron, tin, lead,
31.23: or anything else that can survive a refiner's fire: You are to pass it through fire, after which it will be clean. Then it is to be purified with the water of impurity. Everything that cannot survive a refiner's fire is to be washed in water.
31.24: Wash your clothes on the seventh day, after which you will be clean. Then you may enter the camp."
31.26: "Take an inventory of the booty that was taken in the battle, both of humans and of animals. Then you, Eleazar the priest, and the leaders of the fathers of the community
31.27: are to divide the booty between the warriors who went to war and the rest of the community.
31.28: "After this, you are to exact a tribute for the LORD from the soldiers who went to war, consisting of the tribute earned by one person out of every 500, whether from people, cattle, donkeys, or flocks.
31.29: You are to take half their share and give it to Eleazar the priest as a raised offering to the LORD.
31.30: Then take half the share of the Israelis, one drawn out of every 50 people, cattle, donkeys, flocks, and from every animal, then give to the descendants of Levi who maintain the service of the LORD's tent."
31.31: So Moses and Eleazar the priest did what the LORD had commanded Moses.
31.32: The goods confiscated in excess of the war implements that the warriors had gathered included 675,000 sheep,
31.35: 32,000 women who had not had sexual relations with a man.
31.36: Now half of the share of those who went to war numbered 337,500 sheep,
31.37: so the LORD's tribute from the sheep totaled 675.
31.38: The cattle numbered 36,000, so the LORD's tribute totaled 72.
31.39: The donkeys numbered 30,500, so the LORD's tribute totaled 61.
31.40: The people numbered 16,000, so the LORD's tribute totaled 32 people.
31.41: Then Moses gave the tribute, a raised offering to the LORD, to Eleazar the priest, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
31.42: From half of the share of the Israelis that Moses had set aside from the soldiers,
31.43: there were 337,500 sheep for the community,
31.47: Moses took a portion drawn from every 50 Israelis, including from both human and animals, and gave them to the descendants of Levi who maintained the LORD's tent, just as the LORD had commanded him.
31.48: Then the officers in charge of thousands of soldiers, the captains of thousands, and the captains of hundreds approached Moses
31.49: and told him, "Your servants took a count of the soldiers who were under our authority. We didn't miss a single man.
31.50: We've brought offerings to the LORD from whatever each man found—jewel-encrusted gold, anklets, bracelets, signet rings, earrings, and necklaces—to make atonement for ourselves in the LORD's presence."
31.51: Then Moses and Eleazar the priest took the gold from them and everything that was fashioned into jewels.
31.52: The gold for the raised offering that they brought to the LORD totaled 16,750 shekels,
31.53: because every soldier had confiscated war booty for his own use.
31.54: Moses and Eleazar took the gold from the captains of thousands and hundreds and brought it to the Tent of Meeting, to serve as a memorial to the Israelis in the LORD's presence.

32.1: Now, the descendants of Reuben and descendants of Gad happened to be joint owners of a very large herd of cattle. When they observed that Jazer and Gilead were good grazing lands for cattle,
32.2: the descendants of Gad and descendants of Reuben approached Moses, Eleazar the priest, and the leaders of the community and said,
32.3: "Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon—
32.4: the land that the LORD defeated in the sight of the community of Israel—is perfect for cattle and your servants have cattle.
32.5: If we've found favor in your sight, let this land be given to your servants as our possession instead of us crossing the Jordan River."
32.6: "Will your relatives have to go to war while you remain here?" Moses asked the descendants of Gad and descendants of Reuben in response.
32.7: "Why would you discourage the Israelis from crossing over to the land that the LORD has given them?
32.8: That's what your ancestors did when I sent them from Kadesh-barnea to explore the land.
32.9: When they arrived in the Eshcol Valley and saw the land, they discouraged the Israelis from entering the land that the LORD had given them.
32.10: That's why the LORD's anger flared up that day and he promised by an oath that
32.11: Not one of the men who went up from Egypt, from 20 years old and above, will see the land that I promised to give to their ancestors, that is, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, because none of them followed me wholeheartedly,
32.12: except Jephunneh's son Caleb, the Kenizzite, and Nun's son Joshua. They've wholeheartedly followed the LORD.'
32.13: "The LORD's anger had flared up against Israel so that he made them wander in the wilderness for 40 years until that whole generation, who committed evil in the eyes of the LORD, had died.
32.14: And now, look! You're acting just like your ancestors, like a brood of sinful men, who are provoking the fierce anger of the LORD against the Israelis one step at a time.
32.15: If you stop following him, he will once again abandon them in the wilderness. You'll end up destroying this entire people."
32.16: Then they approached him and said, "Here's where we're going to build corrals for our cattle and cities for our families,
32.17: but we will keep ourselves armed and stay ready to go with the Israelis until we've brought them to their own places. Our families intend to live in fortified cities in the presence of the inhabitants of the land,
32.18: but we won't return to our homes until every Israeli has taken possession of each of their inheritances,
32.19: since our inheritance will not be with them across the Jordan River and beyond. Instead, our inheritance is on this side of the Jordan River, facing eastward."
32.20: "If you do this," Moses replied to them, "that is, if you equip yourselves for war in the LORD's presence
32.21: and every one of your armed soldiers crosses over the Jordan River in the presence of the LORD until he has dispossessed his enemies ahead of him
32.22: and subjugated the land before him, then afterwards when you return, you'll be able to stand blameless before the LORD and before Israel. This land will then be your possession before the LORD.
32.23: "But if you won't do so, look out! You will be sinning against the LORD. Be certain of this, that your sin will catch up to you!
32.24: So after you've built cities for your families and corrals for your cattle, be sure to keep your promises."
32.25: Then the descendants of Gad and descendants of Reuben spoke up. "Your servants will do exactly what our master has commanded." They said.
32.26: "Our children, wives, flocks, and all our cattle will be settled in the cities of Gilead,
32.27: but every soldier that we've equipped for battle will cross the Jordan River in the presence of the LORD, as our master has spoken."
32.28: So Moses instructed Eleazar the priest and Nun's son Joshua, and the officers of the ancestral tribes of the Israelis,
32.29: telling them, "If the descendants of Gad and descendants of Reuben cross over the Jordan River with you, that is, all of their soldiers who've been equipped for battle in the LORD's presence, so that the land is subjugated right before your eyes, then you are to give them the land of Gilead as their possession.
32.30: But if the armed men don't cross over with you, then they won't have any possession in the land of Canaan."
32.31: "We'll do just what the LORD told your servants," the descendants of Gad and the descendants of Reuben responded.
32.32: "We are to cross over in battle array in the LORD's presence into the land of Canaan, and afterwards the possession of our inheritance will be on this side of the Jordan River."
32.33: So Moses gave to the descendants of Gad, to the descendants of Reuben, and to the half-tribe of Joseph's son Manasseh the kingdom of Sihon, the king of the Amorites, and the kingdom of Og, the king of Bashan, the whole land with its cities, and even the territories surrounding it.
32.34: The descendants of Gad rebuilt Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,
32.36: Beth-nimrah, and Beth-haran as fortified cities with corrals for sheep.
32.37: The descendants of Reuben rebuilt Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,
32.38: Nebo, Baal-meon (after having changed their names), and Sibmah. The cities that they rebuilt were renamed.
32.39: The descendants of Manasseh's son Machir attacked Gilead and then captured and dispossessed the Amorites who were there.
32.40: That's why Moses gave Gilead to Manasseh's son Machir, who lived there at the time.
32.41: Manasseh's son Jair captured their towns and renamed them Havvoth-jair.
32.42: Nobah captured Kenath and its towns and renamed it Nobah after himself.

33.1: Here's the travel itinerary for the Israelis after they left the land of Egypt in groups under the authority of Moses and Aaron.
33.2: Moses recorded their departures in their travels after being commanded to do so by the LORD. Here's a list of their travels based on their departures:
33.3: They departed from Rameses in the first month, on the fifteenth day of that first month. The day after the Passover, the Israelis came out confidently, and all the Egyptians watched them leave,
33.4: while they were burying their firstborn, whom the LORD had killed among them. The LORD also executed justice against their gods.
33.5: Then the Israelis traveled from Rameses and rested in Succoth.
33.6: They traveled from Succoth, then rested in Etham, which is at the outskirts of the wilderness.
33.7: They traveled from Etham but turned back to Pi-hahiroth, which is outside of Baal-zephon. They rested outside of Migdol.
33.8: They traveled from Hahiroth and passed through the midst of the sea to the wilderness. They were on the road three days in the wilderness of Etham, then rested in Marah.
33.9: They traveled from Marah and arrived at Elim. In Elim there were twelve wells of water and 70 palm trees, so they rested there.
33.10: They traveled from Elim, then rested by the Reed Sea.
33.11: They traveled from the Reed Sea, then rested in the Wilderness of Zin.
33.12: They traveled from the Wilderness of Zin, then rested in Dophkah.
33.13: They traveled from Dophkah, then rested in Alush.
33.14: They traveled from Alush, then rested in Rephidim, but there was no water there for the people to drink.
33.15: They traveled from Rephidim, then rested in the Wilderness of Sinai.
33.16: They traveled from the Wilderness of Sinai, then rested in Kibroth-hattaavah.
33.17: They traveled from Kibroth-hattaavah, then rested in Hazeroth.
33.18: They traveled from Hazeroth, then rested in Rithmah.
33.19: They traveled from Rithmah, then rested in Rimmon-perez.
33.20: They traveled from Rimmon-perez, then rested in Libnah.
33.21: They traveled from Libnah, then rested in Rissah.
33.22: They traveled from Rissah, then rested in Kehelathah.
33.23: They traveled from Kehelathah, then rested at Mount Shepher.
33.24: They traveled from Mount Shepher, then rested in Haradah.
33.25: They traveled from Haradah, then rested in Makheloth.
33.26: They traveled from Makheloth, then rested in Tahath.
33.27: They traveled from Tahath, then rested in Terah.
33.28: They traveled from Terah, then rested in Mithkah.
33.29: They traveled from Mithkah, then rested in Hashmonah.
33.30: They traveled from Hashmonah, then rested in Moseroth.
33.31: They traveled from Moseroth, then rested in Bene-jaakan.
33.32: They traveled from Bene-jaakan, then rested in Hor-haggidgad.
33.33: They traveled from Hor-haggidgad, then rested in Jotbathah.
33.34: They traveled from Jotbathah, then rested in Abronah.
33.35: They traveled from Abronah, then rested in Ezion-geber.
33.36: They traveled from Ezion-geber, then rested in the Wilderness of Zin, which is also known as Kadesh.
33.37: They traveled from Kadesh, then rested in Mount Hor at the outskirts of the land of Edom.
33.38: Then Aaron the priest ascended Mount Hor in obedience to the LORD's command and died there, in the fortieth year after the Israelis had come out of the land of Egypt, on the first day of the fifth month.
33.39: Aaron was 123 years old when he died on Mount Hor.
33.40: Meanwhile, the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev in the land of Canaan, heard of the approach of the Israelis,
33.41: who had traveled from Mount Hor and then rested in Zalmonah.
33.42: They traveled from Zalmonah, then rested in Punon.
33.43: They traveled from Punon, then rested in Oboth.
33.44: They traveled from Oboth, then rested in Iye-abarim at the outskirts of Moab.
33.45: They traveled from Iyim, then rested in Dibon-gad.
33.46: They traveled from Dibon-gad, then rested in Almon-diblathaim.
33.47: They traveled from Almon-diblathaim, then rested in the mountains of Abarim, facing Nebo.
33.48: They traveled from the mountains of Abarim, then rested in the plains of Moab by the Jordan River, across from Jericho.
33.49: They rested by the Jordan River in the area from Beth-jeshimoth to Abel-shittim in the plains of Moab.
33.50: Then the LORD told Moses in the plains of Moab by the Jordan River, across from Jericho,
33.51: "Tell the Israelis that when they have crossed the Jordan River to the land of Canaan,
33.52: they are to drive out all the inhabitants of the land and destroy all their idols and their molten images. You are to demolish all their high places,
33.53: take possession of the land, and live in it, because I've given you the land to inherit.
33.54: You are to divide the land among yourselves by lot according to your families. The larger the families are in number, the larger their inheritance is to be. The fewer the families are in number, the lesser their inheritance is to be. To whomever the lot falls, that inheritance goes to him. Divide it according to your ancestral tribes.
33.55: But if you fail to drive out the inhabitants of the land before you, their survivors will become irritants in your eyes and thorns in your sides, to prick your sides and afflict you in the very land in which you'll be living.
33.56: Then, what I had planned to do to them, I'll start to do to you."

34.2: "Issue these orders to the Israelis: 'You're about to enter the land of Canaan. This territory has been apportioned to you as your inheritance: the entire land of Canaan, all the way to its borders.'"
34.3: "'To your south is the Wilderness of Zin, bordering Edom. Your southern border is to extend east toward the far end of the Dead Sea,
34.4: then it is to turn southward to the ascent of Akrabbim, cross Zin, and then run south of Kadesh-barnea and proceed from there to Hazar-addar and across to Azmon.
34.5: Then the border is to turn from Azmon toward the wadi of Egypt and from there to the Mediterranean Sea.'"
34.6: "'The western border is to be the Mediterranean Sea. This is to be the western border.'"
34.7: "'Your northern border is to extend from the Mediterranean Sea to Mount Hor.
34.8: From Mount Hor, you are to mark out the entrance to Hammath, with the border running through Zedad,
34.9: then through Ziphron, and then to Hazar-enan. This is to be the northern border.'"
34.10: "'You are to mark the border on the east from Hazar-enan to Shepham.
34.11: The border is then to extend from Shepham to Riblah, on the east side of Ain, then to the Sea of Chinnereth on the east.
34.12: The border is to continue along the Jordan River all the way to the Dead Sea. This is to be your land, as measured by its boundaries.'"
34.13: Moses commanded the Israelis, "You are to inherit this land by lot, just as the LORD commanded to give it to the remaining nine and a half tribes.
34.14: The tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh, as defined by their ancestral houses, have received their inheritance.
34.15: These two and a half tribes received their inheritance this side of the Jordan River, east of Jericho, facing the rising sun."
34.17: "These are the names of the men who are to divide the land for your inheritance: Eleazar the priest and Nun's son Joshua.
34.18: You are to appoint a leader from each tribe to divide the land for inheritance.
34.19: These are the names of the men: Appoint Jephunneh's son Caleb from the tribe of Judah,
34.20: Ammihud's son Shemuel from the tribe of Simeon,
34.21: Chislon's son Elidad from the tribe of Benjamin,
34.22: and Jogli's son Bukki is to be leader of the tribe of Dan.
34.23: From the tribe of Joseph, you are to appoint Ephod's son Hanniel to be leader of the half tribe of Manasseh,
34.24: Shiphtan's son Kemuel to be leader of the half tribe of Ephraim,
34.25: Parnach's son Elizaphan to be leader of the tribe of Zebulun,
34.26: Azzan's son Paltiel to be leader of the tribe of Issachar,
34.27: Shelomi's son Ahihud to be leader of the tribe of Asher,
34.28: and Ammihud's son Pedahel to be leader of the tribe of Naphtali."
34.29: These are the ones whom the LORD commanded to divide the inheritance of the Israelis in the land of Canaan.

35.1: The LORD told Moses in the wilderness of Moab, beside the Jordan River near Jericho,
35.2: "Instruct the Israelis to set aside a portion of their inheritance for the descendants of Levi to live in, along with grazing land surrounding their towns.
35.3: The towns are to be reserved for their dwelling places and the grazing lands are to be reserved for their cattle, livestock, and all their animals.
35.4: The grazing lands that you are to reserve for use by the descendants of Levi are to extend 1,000 cubits from the walls of the town.
35.5: You are to measure from outside the wall of the town on the east side 2,000 cubits, on the south side 2,000 cubits, on the west side 2,000 cubits, and on the north side 2,000 cubits, with the town placed at the center. This reserved area is to serve as grazing land for their towns.
35.6: You are to set aside six towns of refuge from the towns that you will be giving to the descendants of Levi, where someone who kills a human being may run for shelter. In addition, give them 42 other towns.
35.7: The total number of towns that you are to give to the descendants of Levi is to be 48 towns, including grazing lands surrounding these towns.
35.8: You are to apportion the towns that you will be giving the Israelis according to the relative size of the tribe. Take a larger portion from those larger in number and a lesser portion from those fewer in number. Each is to set aside towns for the descendants of Levi proportional to the size of their inheritance that they receive."
35.10: "Tell the Israelis that when they have crossed the Jordan River into the land of Canaan,
35.11: they are to designate some towns of refuge so that anyone who kills someone inadvertently may flee there.
35.12: They are to serve as cities of refuge from a blood avenger in order to keep the inadvertent killer from dying until he has stood trial in the presence of the community.
35.13: You are to set aside six towns of refuge.
35.14: Appoint three towns this side of the Jordan River and three towns in the land of Canaan to serve as the towns of refuge,
35.15: that is, places of refuge for the Israelis, the resident alien, and any travelers among them. Anyone who kills a person inadvertently may flee there."
35.16: "Whoever uses an iron implement to kill someone is to be adjudged a murderer, and that murderer is certainly to be put to death.
35.17: Furthermore, whoever uses a stone implement to kill someone is to be adjudged a murderer, and that murderer is certainly to be put to death.
35.18: Also, whoever uses a wooden implement to kill someone with it is to be adjudged a murderer, and that murderer is certainly to be put to death.
35.19: The blood avenger himself is to execute the murderer. When he meets him, the blood avenger is to put him to death.
35.20: If the killer shoved his victim out of hatred, or hurled something at him while waiting in ambush so that he died,
35.21: or if he struck him with his hand out of hatred so that he died, then the killer is certainly to be put to death for murder. The avenger of blood is to put him to death when he meets him."
35.22: "But if he pushed him suddenly without hatred, or if he hurled something in his direction without waiting in ambush,
35.23: or if he hit him with a stone carelessly so that he was fatally injured, though he isn't his enemy and he wasn't seeking to commit evil against him,
35.24: then the community is to judge between the inadvertent killer and the blood avenger, following these ordinances.
35.25: The community is to release the inadvertent killer from the blood avenger and return him to the town of refuge where he had fled. He is to live there until the High Priest dies, who will have anointed him with holy oil.
35.26: But if the inadvertent killer leaves the town of refuge where he had fled
35.27: and the blood avenger finds him outside the town of refuge where he had fled and kills him, the blood avenger is not to be found guilty of murder.
35.28: The inadvertent killer is to live in the town of refuge until the High Priest dies. After the death of the High Priest, the inadvertent killer is to return to the land of his inheritance.
35.29: These are to be the statutes and ordinances for you throughout all your generations, regardless of where you live."
35.30: "Every murderer of a human being is to be executed only according to testimony given by multiple witnesses. A single witness is not to result in a death sentence.
35.31: You are to receive no ransom for the life of a killer who is guilty of murder; instead, he is to die.
35.32: You are not to receive payment of a ransom for someone who had fled to a town of refuge but then left to live in his homeland before the death of the high priest.
35.33: You are not to pollute the land where you live, because blood defiles the land, and the land cannot atone for blood that has been spilled on it, except through the blood of the one who spilled it.
35.34: You are not to defile the land where you will be living, because I'm living among you. I am the LORD, who lives in Israel."

36.1: The leaders of the ancestral families of the descendants of Gilead, who were descendants of Machir, and descendants of Manasseh, from Joseph's tribe, approached and spoke to Moses and the leaders of the ancestral houses of the Israelis.
36.2: "The LORD commanded my master to apportion the land as an inheritance by lot to the Israelis," they said. "Now my master was ordered by the LORD to give the inheritance of our brother Zelophehad to his daughters.
36.3: But when they get married to one of the descendants of the tribes of Israel, their inheritances are to be withdrawn from our father's inheritance and added to the inheritance of the tribe to which they are to belong. Consequently, it is to be withdrawn from the portion of our inheritance.
36.4: Then, when the Jubilee Year of the Israelis comes, their inheritance will be added to the inheritance of the tribe to which they have come to belong. Their inheritance will thus be taken away from the inheritance of our father's tribe!"
36.5: So Moses issued the Israelis these orders based on what the LORD said: "The tribe of the descendants of Joseph has spoken.
36.6: This is what the LORD is commanding the daughters of Zelophehad: If they decide it's a good idea in their opinion to get married only within the family of their father's tribe, then let them get married
36.7: so that the inheritance of the Israelis won't be turned over from one tribe to another. Each one has an inheritance from his own father's tribe that the Israelis are to maintain.
36.8: Every daughter who is in possession of an inheritance from the Israelis is to marry someone from the families within her father's tribe so the Israelis can retain possession of their ancestral inheritance.
36.9: That way, their inheritance won't be turned over from one tribe to another, because the Israelis are each to maintain their ancestral inheritances."
36.10: Zelophehad's daughters did just what the LORD had commanded Moses
36.11: for Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah: Zelophehad's daughters married their uncle's sons.
36.12: They married into families of the descendants of Manasseh, that is, Joseph's descendants, so that their inheritance remained within the tribe of their ancestor's family.
36.13: These were the commands and the ordinances that the LORD issued to the Israelis through Moses in the plains of Moab by the Jordan River in Jericho.

1.1: These are the words that Moses spoke to the assembly of Israel east of the Jordan River, in the Arabah desert, opposite Suph between Paran, Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Di-zahab.
1.2: It takes eleven days to travel from Horeb to Kadesh-barnea via Mount Seir.
1.3: On the first day of the eleventh month, in the fortieth year, Moses spoke to the Israelis about everything that the LORD had commanded him concerning them.
1.4: This took place after he defeated Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon and Og, king of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth at Edrei.
1.5: East of the Jordan River, in the land of Moab, Moses began to expound this Law:
1.6: "The LORD our God spoke to us in Horeb. He said, 'You have been at this mountain long enough.
1.7: Break camp, get going, and proceed to the hill country of the Amorites and all the nearby places in the Arabah desert, the highlands, the foothills, the Negev, the coastal plains, all of the land of the Canaanites, and Lebanon as far as the great river, the Euphrates.
1.8: Look! I've given you the land that lies ahead. Go in and possess the land that I, the LORD, promised to give to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, as well as to their descendants.'"
1.9: "I also told you at that time that I won't be able to sustain you on my own.
1.10: The LORD your God greatly multiplied your numbers, and today you are like the stars in the sky.
1.11: May the LORD, the God of your ancestors, increase your numbers a thousand times more, and may he bless you, as he promised you.
1.12: How can I bear the burden of you and your bickering all by myself?
1.13: Choose for yourselves wise and discerning men, known to your tribes, and appoint them as your leaders.
1.14: You answered by saying that this plan is a good thing.
1.15: So I chose leaders from your tribes, wise and respected men, and I appointed them over you—commanders of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
1.16: I charged your judges at that time, 'When you hold a hearing between brothers, judge fairly between a man and his brother or between foreigners.
1.17: When you hold a hearing, don't be partial in judgment toward the least important or toward the great. Never fear men, because judgment belongs to God. If the matter is difficult for you, bring it to me for a hearing.'
1.18: I charged you at that time that you must do all of these things."
1.19: "Then we set out from Horeb and walked through that vast and dreadful desert, where you observed the road to the Amorite hill country. Just as the LORD our God ordained for us, we finally arrived at Kadesh-barnea.
1.20: I told you at that time, 'You have reached the hill country of the Amorites, which the LORD our God is about to give us.
1.21: Look! The LORD your God has given the land that lies before you. Go and possess it, just as the LORD God of your ancestors commanded you. Don't be afraid or discouraged.'
1.22: "Then all of you approached me and said: 'Let's send out men in advance of us so they can survey the land and bring back a report to us on how we'll go up to their cities.'
1.23: Because this suggestion seemed good to me, I chose twelve men from among you, one from each tribe.
1.24: Then these men set out, went up to the hill county, reached the Eshcol Valley, and surveyed it.
1.25: They hand-picked some of the fruit of the land, brought it down to us, and gave a report that said, 'The land which the LORD is about to give us is good.'"
1.26: "However, your ancestors didn't go up. Instead, they rebelled against the command of the LORD your God.
1.27: You murmured in your tents, 'The LORD hates us. He brought us out of the land of Egypt in order to deliver us to the Amorites so he could destroy us.
1.28: Where can we go? Our brothers discouraged us when they said that the people are bigger and taller than we are. Their cities are tall and fortified to the sky, and we also saw the Anakim there.'
1.29: "Then I told you, 'Don't be terrified or afraid of them.
1.30: The LORD your God is the One who will be going ahead of you. He'll fight for you just as he did in Egypt before your eyes.
1.31: In the desert you saw that the LORD carried you like a man carries his son, on every road you traveled until you reached this place.'
1.32: But despite this, you didn't trust in the LORD your God,
1.33: who walked ahead of you along the way to scout a place for you to pitch camp—by fire at night and cloud by day—to lead you on the way you should go."
1.34: "When the LORD heard your complaints, he became angry and declared,
1.35: I swear that not one man of this evil generation will see the good land that I promised to give to your ancestors,
1.36: except Jephunneh's son Caleb. He will see it and I will give to him and to his descendants the land on which he has walked because he wholeheartedly followed the LORD.'
1.37: "The LORD was also furious with me because of you. He said: 'You will not enter the land.
1.38: However, Nun's son Joshua, your assistant, will go there. Encourage him, for he will cause Israel to take possession of it.
1.39: Your little ones—whom you said would be taken captive—and your children who do not yet know right from wrong will enter the land. I will give it to them and they themselves will possess it.
1.40: But as for you, prepare to set out for the desert on the way to the Reed Sea.'
1.41: "You responded to me and said, 'We have sinned against the LORD. We will now go up and fight according to what the LORD our God commanded.' So each man put on his weapon for battle and recklessly started out for the hill country."
1.42: "Then the LORD told me: 'Tell them not to go up and fight because I will not be in their midst, or else you will be defeated before your enemies.'
1.43: "I spoke to you but you didn't listen. Instead you rebelled against the command of the LORD and went up to the hill country.
1.44: The Amorites who lived in the hill country came out to engage you in battle. They pursued you like bees do and crushed you from Seir to Hormah.
1.45: You returned and cried out in the LORD's presence, but the LORD didn't hear your voice or listen to you.
1.46: You remained in Kadesh for many days. It was a long time, indeed."

2.1: "We turned and set out for the desert on the road to the Reed Sea, just as the LORD had directed me. We traveled around Mount Seir for many days.
2.3: You've walked around this mountain long enough. Turn northward
2.4: and command this people, "You are about to pass through the territory of your relatives, the descendants of Esau who live around Seir. They will be afraid of you so be very careful.
2.5: Don't fight them, because I won't give you any part of their land, not even the size of a footprint. I have given Mount Seir to Esau as their property.
2.6: You may buy food to eat and water to drink from them, paying with cash."'
2.7: Indeed, the LORD your God blessed all the works of your hands. He knows about your travels through this vast desert. The LORD your God was with you these past 40 years, so that you didn't lack anything.
2.8: So we bypassed our relatives, the descendants of Esau who live in Seir. We turned through the Arabah desert from Elath, and from Ezion-geber we traveled the desert road to Moab."
2.9: "Then the LORD told me, 'Don't harass Moab or provoke them to war, because I won't give you any part of their land. I have given Ar to the descendants of Lot as their property.
2.10: (The Emites, a people as powerful, numerous, and tall as the Anakim, lived there before.
2.11: Like the Anakim, they were thought of as Rephaim, but the Moabites called them Emites.
2.12: The Horites used to live in Seir before the descendants of Esau dispossessed them, exterminated them, and settled there instead, just as Israel will do in the land of its possession, which the LORD gave them.)
2.13: Now get going and cross the Wadi Zered.' And so we crossed the Wadi Zered.
2.14: Now from the time we left Kadesh-barnea until we crossed the Wadi Zered was 38 years. All of that generation, the soldiers in the camp, were destroyed just as the LORD swore they would be.
2.15: Indeed, the hand of the LORD was against them to root them out from the camp until they were utterly destroyed."
2.16: "And so all the soldiers among the people died.
2.17: Then the LORD spoke to me,
2.18: Today, you are about to cross the border of Moab at Ar.
2.19: When you come to the Ammonites, don't harass or provoke them to war, for I won't give any part of Ammonite land to you, since I have given it to the descendants of Lot as their property.
2.20: "'(Indeed, it was considered Rephaim territory, since the Rephaim used to lived there. The Ammonites called them Zamzummites,
2.21: a great people, numerous, and tall as the Anakim. But the LORD destroyed the Rephaim, so that the Ammonites dispossessed them and settled there instead.
2.22: This is what he did for the descendants of Esau who live in Seir, when he destroyed the Horites before them. So they dispossessed them and settled there in their place, where they live to this day.
2.23: It was the same for the Avvites who lived in villages as far as Gaza. The Caphtorites, who came from Crete, destroyed them and settled there in their place.)
2.24: Get ready and set out for the Wadi Arnon. Look! I've given into your control Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, along with his land. Prepare to take possession by provoking him to war.
2.25: Starting today I will begin to instill fear and terror of you on the part of every nation under heaven who hears reports about you. They'll tremble in anguish before you.'"
2.26: "I sent messengers from the desert of Kedemoth to King Sihon of Heshbon with this message of peace:
2.27: Let me pass through your territory. I'll stay on the main road. I won't turn to the right or left.
2.28: Sell me food for cash, so I can eat and give me water for cash, so I can drink. Just let me pass through on foot,
2.29: as the descendants of Esau who live in Seir did for me, as did the Moabites who live in Ar. I'll pass through, until I will have crossed the Jordan into the land that the LORD our God is about to give us.'
2.30: But King Sihon of Heshbon did not allow us to pass through, because the LORD your God had hardened his spirit and made him arrogant, in order to deliver him into your control today.
2.31: "Then the LORD told me, 'See, I've begun to deliver Sihon and his territory over to you. Prepare to take possession of his land.'
2.32: "Sihon came out to meet us, including his entire army, at the battle of Jahaz.
2.33: The LORD our God delivered him to us, so we attacked him, his son, and his whole army.
2.34: We captured all his towns at that time. We utterly destroyed every town—the men, the women, and the children—leaving no survivors.
2.35: We only appropriated the livestock for our use, along with plunder from the cities that we captured.
2.36: From Aroer on the edge of Arnon Valley and from the town all the way to Gilead, there was no city that was too strong for us—the LORD our God delivered them all to us.
2.37: You did not encroach onto Ammonite land, the banks of the Wadi Jabbok, the towns in the hill country, and all the other places that were forbidden by the LORD our God."

3.1: "We set out and went up along the road to Bashan. Then King Og of Bashan came out to meet us—he and his whole army—for a battle at Edrei.
3.2: Then the LORD told me, 'Don't fear him, because I've delivered him, his army, and his territory into your control. Do to him just as you have done to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon.'
3.3: "So the LORD our God also delivered into our control King Og of Bashan, along with his whole army. We attacked him until there were no survivors.
3.4: Then we captured all his cities at that time. There was not a city left that we didn't capture from them—60 cities in all from the region of Argob, which is part of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
3.5: All of these cities were fortified with high walls, gates, and bars. Furthermore, there were very many unwalled regions.
3.6: We utterly destroyed them, just as we did King Sihon of Heshbon, attacking them in every city—the men, women, and children.
3.7: But we kept for ourselves all of the livestock and plunder from the towns.
3.8: "So at that time, we took control from the two Amorite kings the territory east of the Jordan from Wadi Arnon to Mount Hermon.
3.9: (The Sidonians called Hermon Sirion, but the Amorites called it Senir.)
3.10: We took control of all the cities of the plain, all of Gilead and Bashan as far as Salecah and Edrei, cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
3.11: Only King Og of Bashan remained from the remnants of the Rephaim. In fact, his bed was made of iron. It's in Rabbah of the Ammonites, isn't it? It was nine cubits long and four cubits wide."
3.12: "Of the land that we captured at that time, I've given its towns to the descendants of Reuben and the descendants of Gad from Aroer near the Wadi Arnon to half of the hill country of Gilead.
3.13: The remainder of Gilead and Bashan of the kingdom of Og, I've given to the half-tribe of Manasseh. (The whole region of Argob—that is, all of Bashan—is called the land of the Rephaim.)
3.14: Manasseh's son Jair captured all the Argob region as far as the territory of the descendants of Geshur and the descendants of Maacath. Bashan was named after him; that's why it is called Havvoth-jair to this day.
3.15: Furthermore, I've given Gilead to Machir.
3.16: And I've given Gilead to the descendants of Reuben and the descendants of Gad as far as the Arnon Valley, designating the middle of the valley as its boundary, including up to the Jabbok River as a boundary with the Ammonites.
